AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	1	192	Senior Red Cross officials who visited Pakistan's Swat Valley said Sunday they were "gravely concerned" over the humanitarian situation as Pakistani soldiers battled to crush the Taliban. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	2	389	"The organisation is gravely concerned about the plight of civilians in Swat and believes their situation demands a prompt and comprehensive humanitarian response," said a statement released from the Geneva headquarters of the International Committee for the Red Cross (ICRC). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	3	675	"The ICRC will do its utmost to meet those needs without delay," said Pascal Cuttat, head of the organisation's delegation in Pakistan. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	4	820	"Given what we have already seen on the ground, we are mobilising additional resources, but safe and unimpeded access to the area remains essential for our teams to deliver," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	5	1014	Aid workers had been alarmed at what they saw when they entered the region, where the fighting between the Pakistani army and Taliban fighters for the pass month has left civilians trapped and isolated for weeks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	6	1236	"There is no running water, no electricity, and food is scarce," said Daniel O'Malley, who led the IRCR team into the region. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	7	1371	"Phone lines are down, so people have been cut off from the outside world and are anxious for contact with relatives who fled the area," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	8	1527	Red Cross workers were also disturbed at conditions in Khwazakhela hospital, one of the few medical facilities still left operating in Swat. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	9	1677	"The handful of hospital staff left are struggling to work without any water, electricity or supplies," said O'Malley. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	10	1805	"They simply cannot cope with the influx of patients." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	11	1869	The Red Cross evacuated 14 patients from the hospital. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	12	1933	Pakistan's defence secretary Syed Athar Ali said Sunday the army was gaining on the Taliban and fighting could be over in a few days. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	13	2076	Swat valley's main town Mingora is back in government hands, a critical milestone in an offensive launched after the Taliban thrust to within 100 kilometres (60 miles) of Islamabad in April. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	14	2276	The defence chief told a security forum in Singapore that three targeted northwest districts were almost clear of Taliban rebels. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	15	2415	"Only five to 10 percent of the job is remaining and hopefully within the next two to three days these pockets of resistance will be cleared," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	16	2576	The United States, which is firmly backing the current military drive, had warned that the rebels threaten Pakistan's very existence. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	17	2719	Also Sunday the military relaxed a curfew Sunday in most parts of the northwest including Mingora to allow people trapped on the roads to return home or leave the region. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	18	2899	The ICRC is one of the very few humanitarian organizations working in Swat before the conflict broke out and has been trying to return there since early this month. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	19	3064	Despite some openings it said access to areas affected by the fighting remains too limited. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0154	20	3165	It also continues to support camps run by the Pakistan Red Crescent Society, where over 20,000 people driven from their homes by the fighting are currently living.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0155	2	353	In one of the greatest upsets in the tournament's history, the Spanish king of clay slumped to a first ever defeat here having racked up 31 wins in 31 outings since his 2005 debut. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0155	3	543	Soderling's stunning 6-2, 6-7 (2/7), 6-4, 7-6 (7/2) victory came just a month after he'd won only one game in a 6-1, 6-0 rout at the Rome Masters, his third defeat in three matches against the world number one. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0155	4	763	But he was man transformed on Sunday with the 24-year-old unleashing a formidable service game and a relentless, pinpoint accurate forehand which forced Nadal to constantly scramble for a foothold in the match. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0155	5	983	Nadal's first set loss was the first time he had dropped a set in the tournament since the 2007 final against Roger Federer, ending a run of 32 in a row.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0155	9	1663	Nadal, despite missing his usual fluency and rattled by the unrelenting assault, broke for the first time to lead 2-1 in the second set only to surrender his advantage in the 10th game. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0155	10	1858	With most people inside Court Philippe Chatrier expecting a Nadal drive to fly past the big Swede, Soderling executed a fine backhand volley to go to 5-5. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0155	11	2022	Despite those heroics, Nadal ran away with the tiebreaker to level the match when, for once, Soderling's forehand missed its target and flew long. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0155	12	2178	The Swede, coached by compatriot and 2000 finalist Magnus Norman, refused to yield, breaking to lead 4-3 before backing it up for a 5-3 advantage in the third set.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0155	14	2455	Nadal broke to lead 2-0 in the fourth set, but Soderling hit back immediately as another tiebreak loomed where the gallant Swede clinched his famous win on a second match point when Nadal went wide with a pick-up.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0167	8	1290	Even more damagingly, it suggested Labour would also come third in a general election with just 22 percent of the vote -- the worst Brown's party has done in an opinion poll since 1987.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0167	10	1636	ICM interviewed 1,013 adults by telephone between May 27-28. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0167	11	1706	But Brown, who must call a general election by the middle of next year, dismissed suggestions he could step down to make way for a more popular leader in an interview with BBC television. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0167	12	1903	"Things go up and down," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0167	13	1937	"We're going through the most difficult economic circumstances the country has faced. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0167	14	2032	"People are angry rightly because they are worried when they see taxpayers' money wasted on their MPs and they're finding it very difficult... in a difficult economic situation," he added, referring to Britain's recession. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0167	15	2264	He also said he wanted to introduce a "constitutional renewal" bill and was looking at reforms including the case for a written constitution, lowering the voting age to 16 and reform of the unelected upper chamber, the House of Lords. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0167	16	2508	Brown said he did not accept the case for an unelected House of Lords and said he was always open to arguments for reforming of the voting system. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0167	17	2664	Cameron, meanwhile, renewed his calls for a snap general election, telling the BBC the public wanted to "sit in judgement on MPs". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0167	18	2804	Turnout at European elections in Britain is usually low -- in the last polls in 2004, it was just 38 percent, due in part to strong Eurosceptic sentiment among many. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0167	19	2979	This time, fringe parties such as the anti-EU UK Independence Party and the far- right British National Party are expected to benefit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0167	20	3114	Commentators say the BNP could even win its first seat at the European Parliament. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0167	21	3206	An Economist magazine/YouGov poll last week found that only 31 percent of Britons think its membership of the European Union is a good thing, compared to 37 percent who think it is bad. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0167	22	3401	A total of 2,322 adults in Britain were questioned between May 22 and May 26.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0173	0	58	Tennis: Azarenka dethrones Queen Ana at French Open 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0173	1	182	Belarussian teenager Victoria Azarenka sunk Ana Ivanovic's hopes of defending her French Open crown with a comprehensive 6-2, 6-3 win in the fourth round on Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0173	2	356	It is the first time the 19-year-old has reached the last eight at a Grand Slam event and she will play Russian top seed Dinara Safina for a place in the semi- finals. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0173	3	533	The 21-year-old Ivanovic, meanwhile, was left pondering what she has to do to re-discover the form that brought her the title and world No.1 spot a year ago. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0173	4	700	Azarenka, with three titles to her name this year already, was the first to break thanks to a blistering crosscourt backhand in the third game. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0173	5	853	Ivanovic, who has battled for form and fitness since her triumph here last year, had her chances to break back in the following game but failed to take them. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0173	6	1020	She paid the penalty for that three games later when Azarenka collected a second break of serve forcing her opponent to hit long on break point at the end of a long, punishing rally. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0173	7	1212	Azarenka, a former world junior No.1, comfortably served out for the set despite opening with a double fault. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0173	8	1331	Both players were wearing high-tech strapping on their knees, the right for Ivanovic and the left for Azarenko, a clear sign of the injury epidemic that has beset women's tennis. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0173	9	1519	Ivanovic was put under severe pressure on her serve again at the start of the second set and after saving a handful of break points she finally succumbed by hitting a forehand a fraction long. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0173	10	1721	That was all Azarenka needed to further assert her authority in the match with Ivanovic looking increasingly out of sorts and unsure of herself. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0173	11	1875	The crowd were firmly behind the Serb, but it made no difference as Azarenko jumped out into a commanding 4-0 lead. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0173	12	2000	Ivanovic did manage to claw two games back to get to 4-2, but Azarenka snuffed out any hope she had of a comeback by breaking the Serbian's serve again in the next game. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0173	13	2179	She failed to serve out for the match but broke Ivanovic for the sixth time in the match in the following game to go through.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0174	2	342	"We are not in favour to see the prices in the hundreds (of dollars a barrel) because this will fuel recession again," the minister told reporters outside parliament. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0174	3	518	He said Kuwait, the fourth largest Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries producer, is happy with OPEC's decision to keep production unchanged and ruled out any output cut when the organisation meets again in September.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0174	5	883	There is a lot of supply but the prices are rising."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0181	1	175	AC Milan booked their place in the Champions League group stages and gave Paolo Maldini a winning send-off as they beat Fiorentina 2-0 on Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0181	2	330	The seven-time European champions risked missing out on a top three finish and having to negotiate two qualifying rounds in Europe next season if they lost but goals from Kaka and Pato were enough to secure a win and third place in Serie A. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0181	3	580	Fiorentina finished fourth following the defeat and will play those two qualifying rounds next season while Juventus claimed second spot with a 2-0 home win over Lazio. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0181	4	758	But while Maldini was afforded a great reception from both sets of fans in Florence to celebrate his 24 years as a Milan player, coach Carlo Ancelotti made what will likely be a more discreet departure. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0181	5	970	He too is likely to leave Milan to join Chelsea next season, despite Milan's fans chanting for him to stay throughout the game. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0181	6	1107	Fiorentina, who had to win to take a top three finish, started brightly and former Milan forward Alberto Gilardino got on the end of a left-wing cross on 22-minutes but headed wide under pressure. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0181	7	1313	Just two minutes later former Arsenal star Mathieu Flamini grazed the bar with a vicious shot from 22 yards as Milan demonstrated their potency. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0181	8	1467	Fiorentina had a good shout for a penalty on 42 minutes when Giuseppe Favalli appeared to haul down Gilardino but the referee gave a foul the other way. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0181	9	1629	On 48 minutes the striker went close again as he curled a shot just past the post with the outside of his right boot. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0181	10	1756	But on 55 minutes Milan took the lead with a simple move as Andrea Pirlo released Gianluca Zambrotta down the right and although his cross was blocked by Alessandro Gamberini, Kaka followed up to slide home the ball.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	0	58	Cuba agrees to resume talks with US on migration, mail: US 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	1	194	Cuba has agreed to resume talks with the United States on migration and direct mail, a US official said here Sunday, as a US-Cuban thaw gathers pace under President Barack Obama's administration. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	2	399	The announcement came as Secretary of State Hillary Clinton prepared to attend Tuesday's Organization of American States (OAS) general assembly in Honduras, where Washington and its southern neighbors have been caught in a row over the pace of normalization with Cuba. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	3	677	The Cuban government informed Washington on Saturday that it "would like to resume migration talks.... 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	4	780	(and) engage in talks on direct mail service," the senior State Department official told reporters on the condition of anonymity. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	5	919	"We and the Cubans have to determine a mutually convenient place and time," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	6	1014	The official said the Cubans "also indicated they would like to explore areas of additional dialogue," such as in counter-narcotics, counter-terrorism, hurricane and disaster preparedness response. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	7	1221	US officials said May 23 that the Obama administration had proposed to resume the discussions on migration issues, which had been conducted every two years until they were suspended in 2003 by former president George W. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	8	1441	Bush. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	9	1456	It was also Washington that recently proposed to resume direct mail, the official said, adding mail has for years, if not decades, been sent between the United States and Cuba through a third country. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	10	1666	The official called the moves a "very positive development and step forward" as the Obama administration pursues engagement with Cuba, which has been under a decades-old US embargo. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	11	1857	He said diplomatic notes were handed to US officials by Jorge Bolanos, the head of the Cuban interests section in Washington. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	12	1992	Cuba has a longstanding interest in seeing migration dialogue progress. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	13	2064	The Caribbean nation of more than 11 million is bothered by embarrassing illegal emigration by Cubans across the shark-infested Florida Straits. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	14	2218	Havana, the Americas' only one-party communist regime, has long argued the United States should increase its number of standard legal immigration visas for Cubans. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	15	2391	Since coming to office in January, the Obama administration has called past US policy a failure and moved to repair ties with Cuban President Raul Castro, who officially took over the reins from older brother Fidel last year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	16	2626	In April, Obama lifted travel and money transfer restrictions on Cuban-Americans with relatives in Cuba. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	17	2740	When asked if the announcement would affect the OAS meeting on Tuesday in San Pedro Sula, the official said "it is hoped that this will be understood in the region in a positive way." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	18	2933	US officials earlier declined to even rule out the possibility of Clinton's skipping the OAS meeting altogether if negotiators fail to agree on terms for bringing Cuba back within the 35-member organization's fold. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	19	3157	The United States wants Cuba to free political prisoners and respect political freedoms for it to participate fully in the OAS, saying Havana should be held to the democratic principles enshrined in the 2001 OAS charter. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	20	3387	Other OAS members say that Cuba can be nudged toward democracy once part of the international body. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	21	3496	Since a popular Obama took office in January, he has raised hopes among many of his southern neighbors that he will soon lift the controversial embargo, even if he insists that Cuba first undertake democratic reforms. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	22	3723	"This is going to be a complicated challenge for her (Clinton) to deal with," said Michael Shifter, an analyst for the Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington think tank. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	23	3901	"I sense the Obama people are a little bit nervous. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	24	3953	I think they're aware that it's a minefield, Cuba," said Shifter. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0183	25	4028	Clinton was preparing to leave Sunday for El Salvador to attend Monday's inauguration of Mauricio Funes, the first stop on a two-country tour.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0189	0	58	585 Franco symbols still on Spanish public buildings: report 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0189	1	192	Nearly 600 symbols of the right-wing dictatorship of General Francisco Franco still adorn public buildings in Spain more than 30 years after his death, a newspaper reported Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0189	2	382	More than half of the remaining 585 symbols of the regime are on defence ministry buildings as many military leaders are reluctant to have them removed, said the daily newspaper Publico, citing a government report. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0189	3	606	Under a law passed in 2007 by the governing Socialists, towns are obliged to remove public symbols of the Franco era and rename streets named after the dictator or the generals who fought with him in Spain's 1936-1939 civil war. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0189	4	844	But it allows for exceptions to be made if valid artistic, historical or religious reasons are given for a symbol to remain in place. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0189	5	987	The government report cited by Publico was drawn up to determine which symbols of the regime should be "removed, hidden or neutralised" and which should be allowed to remain. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0189	6	1171	The Franco symbols that remain are mostly depictions of the coat of arms of the regime, which include the Eagle of St John. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0189	7	1304	The last public statue of Franco still on display on mainland Spain was taken down from a central square in the northern city of Santander in December 2008. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0189	8	1470	Franco ruled Spain with an iron fist from 1939 until his death in 1975 at the age of 82, which paved the way for the country's return to democracy.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0192	0	58	Danish Tiananmen sculptor denied entry to Hong Kong 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0192	1	186	A Danish sculptor who flew to Hong Kong to protest the bloody crackdown on pro- democracy protests in Beijing 20 years ago has been refused entry to the city, an official and a legislator said Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0192	2	396	Jens Galschiot, whose sculpture commemorating those who died in the 1989 military crackdown, "Pillar of Shame," is displayed at Hong Kong University, was stopped by officials Saturday, an immigration spokesman said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0192	3	621	Albert Ho, the chairman of the Democratic Party and a lawyer, said the Dane was detained for five hours before being put on a flight to Zurich late Saturday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0192	4	788	Galschiot, who was also refused entry to the city ahead of the Beijing Olympics last year, had planned to join the annual June 4 vigil to mark the anniversary of the crackdown. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0192	5	974	In Copenhagen, the sculptor told AFP he thought his being turned back from Hong Kong was retaliation by China for the visit by Tibet's exiled spiritual leader the Dalai Lama in Denmark. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0192	6	1169	"I was supposed to exhibit two bronze sculptures in Hong Kong in remembrance of the 20th anniversary of the bloodly crackdown on protesters in Tiananmen Square," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0192	7	1349	He said he was held by police for about eight hours before being "escorted by two dozen agents to the entrance of the plane" which took him to Copenhagen, where he arrived Sunday morning. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0192	8	1546	He says the only reason he was given for being denied entry to Hong Kong -- although his two sons and a filmmaker with him were allowed into the former British colony -- was "questions of immigration". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0192	9	1757	"This denying me entry without valid reasons shows that Hong Kong, which has a particular status within China and larger freedom, obeys orders from Beijing," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0192	10	1933	Ho, who had been allowed to see Galschiot during his detention, said: "We are looking at the possibility of legal action following the decision." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0192	11	2088	The immigration department spokesman said it had acted in accordance with the law. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0192	12	2180	The 20th anniversary of the crackdown on the protests -- which left hundreds, possibly thousands, dead across the Chinese capital -- will be marked on Thursday in Hong Kong with a candlelight vigil expected to draw tens of thousands. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0192	13	2423	Hong Kong, which has a different legal system from the mainland, is the only place in China where the anniversary is publicly commemorated.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0193	2	363	"We must overcome this phase with all its ramifications and open a new page to build the nation," the emir, Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmad al-Sabah, told the new parliament which was elected on May 16 in snap polls.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0193	4	750	Sheikh Sabah said that the cornerstone for forging ahead with stalled development programmes is through a strong cooperation between the government and the legislature. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0193	5	928	Four women made history when they won seats for the first time in the 50-member parliament, while the election saw the Sunni Islamists reduced to a minority. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0193	6	1095	Three Islamist MPs raised objections when two female MPs and a minister showed up at the inaugural session without the hijab, or head cover, accusing them of violating the election law that requires women to abide by Islamic law. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0193	7	1334	Prime Minister Sheikh Nasser Mohammad al-Ahmad al-Sabah, a nephew of the emir, said his government wants to cooperate with the new parliament to get the country back on development track. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0193	8	1531	But even before new MPs and ministers took the oath, 14 lawmakers walked out of the session in protest against the government's failure to submit its programme and a delayed five-year development plan. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0193	9	1742	Deputy premier for economic affairs Sheikh Ahmad Fahad al-Sabah later told reporters that the government will submit the main guidelines of the five-year plan next month. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0193	10	1922	He also said the government will push for the approval of several economic bills including a privatisation draft law that has been in parliament since 1992. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0193	11	2088	Wealthy businessman Jassem al-Khorafi was unanimously elected speaker for a record fifth consecutive time. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0193	12	2204	The new parliament is due to vote next week on a multi-billion dollar economic stimulus bill which was issued by the previous government when parliament was dissolved. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0193	13	2381	Several MPs have vowed to vote against the legislation, charging that public money was being used to bailout rich people only, ignoring the poor. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0193	14	2536	A group of MPs submitted a draft law calling on the state to purchase billions of dollars of consumer loans for citizens and then reschedule them without interest. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0193	15	2709	Parliament also formed a special committee entrusted to resolve the issue of over 100,000 bidoons, or stateless Arabs, who are living in the emirate but are deprived of their basic rights like education and work.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0193	17	3044	It has 1.1 million of native population besides 2.35 of foreign residents.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	0	58	London's Big Ben ticks over to 150th anniversary 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	1	180	Big Ben, arguably the world's most famous clock which towers over London, marked its 150th anniversary Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	2	300	The clock started ticking on May 31 1859 and has continued with only occasional interruptions for maintenance, bad weather and even bird strikes ever since. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	3	466	The clock, housed in St Stephen's Tower which adjoins Britain's House of Commons, is one of the capital's most popular tourist attractions and boasts some amazing statistics. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	4	650	Each of the four Gothic clock faces is seven metres wide, with a minute hand over four metres long which travels the equivalent of 190 kilometres per year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	5	815	A Latin inscription is carved beneath each one -- "Domine salvam fac Reginam nostrum Victoriam primam" which means: "O Lord, save our Queen Victoria the First." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	6	976	Queen Victoria was on the throne in Britain at the time. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	7	1042	The 96 metre-high tower which houses the clock was built as part of the rebuilding of the Houses of Parliament by architects Charles Barry and Augustus Pugin following a major fire in 1843. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	8	1241	A competition was opened in 1846 to decide who should build the clock, but it took seven years to decide a winner. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	9	1365	Eventually, the winner was named as Edward Dent, who had already made a chronometer for the HMS Beagle, the ship which carried Charles Darwin on a worldwide voyage which led him to the theory of evolution. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	10	1580	The clock cost 2,500 pounds to build and was completed in 1854 but it was not installed until the clock tower was finished five years later. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	11	1730	Even then, there was a last-minute hitch -- the original cast-iron minute hands were too heavy and had to be replaced with copper ones. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	12	1875	The famous bell chimes -- which are used at the start of many television and radio news bulletins in Britain -- did not sound for another six weeks afterwards. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	13	2044	The name Big Ben originally referred to the bell in the clocktower, but has come to be used for the tower and the clock as well. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0195	14	2182	It is not entirely clear where the name Big Ben comes from -- some say refers to Sir Benjamin Hall, an MP at the time, while others claim it was after heavyweight boxer Benjamin Caunt. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0196	0	58	Football: Massoud is hero and villain as holders Sfaxien crash 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0196	1	200	Amir Massoud was the hero and villain as African Confederation Cup holders CS Sfaxien of Tunisia made a shock fourth round exit this weekend despite a 2-0 win over Primeiro Agosto of Angola. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0196	2	400	The club from the Mediterranean town of Sfax entered the second leg at home needing to wipe out a 2-0 deficit from the first encounter against the military club in Luanda two weeks ago.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0196	6	1224	A 2-0 win for the home team meant a shoot-out with five mandatory kicks each and all were converted except that taken by Massoud, giving the visitors a 5-4 victory on penalties.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0196	8	1653	Also through to the group phase of the second-tier African Confederation Cup are Stade Malien, the first Malian club to reach this stage of a competition that replaced the African Cup Winners Cup and CAF Cup five years ago. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0196	9	1886	Boosted by a first-minute goal, Malien defeated Al-Ittihad Khemisset of Morocco 3-1 in Bamako having drawn the first leg and qualified 4-2 on aggregate. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0196	10	2048	Abdoulaye Sidibe put Stade ahead with his first goal of a competition modelled on the European UEFA Cup, staged for the last time this season and won by Ukrainian side Shakhtar Donetsk. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0196	11	2243	Adama Toure scored either side of half-time in the Malian capital to put Stade in a commanding position before Rahhal al-Khaddouri snatched a late consolation goal for the Moroccans.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0196	14	2837	He takes over 2010 African Nations Cup hosts Angola next month, charged with transforming a struggling national team into one capable of winning the biennial showcase of football on the continent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	0	58	Iraq's Kurdish region to export oil for first time 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	1	187	Iraq's self-ruled Kurdish region will begin exporting crude oil for the first time on June 1, piping up to 90,000 bpd to its neighbours in a landmark step for the area, officials said on Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	2	391	Companies chosen by the regional government will pump oil from two Kurdish fields via an Iraqi pipeline to Turkey with the consent of Baghdad in a step that could pave the way to ending bitter domestic feuds over Iraq's oil wealth. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	3	632	Initial exports will be around 40,000 barrels per day from the Taq Taq field in the province of Arbil and another 50,000 bpd from the Tawke field in Dohuk, company officials told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	4	825	"Piping of the oil will start Monday morning from the Taq Taq field, pumping it from seven wells," said Mohammed Okotan, director of the Taq Taq project for Turkey's Genel Enerji, which is partnered with Calgary-based Addax Petroleum. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	5	1069	"We will try to reach 60,000 barrels a day by the end of this year," said Okotan, adding that the project aims to double exports in two years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	6	1221	"The quality of the crude is excellent," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	7	1280	At the Tawke field, northwest of Taq Taq, Norwegian oil firm DNO will also start pumping oil for export on Monday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	8	1404	"We'll start with 50,000 bpd and we'll see how this operation goes and if we can increase it," said DNO director of operations Jon Sargent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	9	1553	Exports from Tawke will link with the Iraq-Turkey main export pipeline at the border town of Fishkhabur, while crude from Taq Taq will be trucked from the capital Arbil before connecting with the Iraq-Turkey export pipeline. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	10	1787	Regional president Massud Barzani will preside over an official ceremony on Monday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	11	1880	Disagreements over oil rights, especially between Baghdad and the Kurdish government, have held up exploitation of much of Iraq's massive reserves as well as long-delayed hydrocarbons legislation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	12	2086	Terms of the Taq Taq deal are for Baghdad to receive 88 percent of revenues of which the Kurd region will get back 17 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	13	2213	Genel Enerji and Addax will share 12 percent, Okotan told reporters. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	14	2291	Executives from DNO refused to provide revenue sharing figures, although one DNO official confided that the terms are quite similar to those in the Taq Taq field. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	15	2463	Baghdad has repeatedly said that it is opposed to Arbil signing its own contracts, a position which Kurdish officials have thumbed their nose at by signings dozens of agreements with foreign firms. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	16	2670	Earlier this month Kurd officials announced an eight billion dollar plan to develop Kurdish gas fields with four European and two United Arab Emirates partners that could later supply the EU's flagship Nabucco pipeline. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	17	2899	Oil minister Hussein al-Shahristani responded by calling the deal illegal, although he has come under heavy criticism for failing to lift the nation's anaemic oil and gas output as crude prices have plunged. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	18	3116	Iraq is in dire need of revenue to rebuild its shattered economy, especially after oil prices tumbled a peak of 147 dollars a barrel last July to a current level just above 60 dollars, putting huge pressure on Iraq's budget. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	19	3350	The nation derives more than 90 percent of its revenues from the energy sector. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	20	3439	Iraq wants pump six million barrels per day, up from its current stated output of around 2.2 million, within the next four to five years as new projects come online. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	21	3614	The conflict-ravaged country has the world's third largest proven reserves of oil, with more than 115 billion barrels, behind only Saudi Arabia and Iran. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	0	58	Breakaway South Ossetia votes for parliament 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	1	189	The rebel Georgian region of South Ossetia voted Sunday in polls expected to secure the grip of its separatist leader nine months after it was the subject of war between Russia and Georgia. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	2	388	The local opposition says Eduard Kokoity is seeking to use the elections to forge a loyal parliamentary majority to push through an amendment allowing him to run again for office when his second term lapses in 2011. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	3	613	Officials estimated the voter turnout at over 70 percent by 4:00 pm (1300 GMT). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	4	693	According to law, the vote is deemed valid if the voter turnout reached 50 percent plus one vote. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	5	800	Voting was due to end at 1600 GMT, with the first results expected two hours later. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	6	893	Russia -- which outraged the West by recognising South Ossetia as independent in the wake of the August war with Georgia --- has said South Ossetia should not amend the existing term limits in its constitution. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	7	1113	Kokoity said, however, it was too early to say whether he planned to run again, although he did not rule out that possibility. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	8	1249	"There are two and half years left till then and a lot left to do. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	9	1316	We are working and working now. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	10	1348	I am not thinking about it yet," he said in an interview with AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	11	1424	"With what happened in August we need three to four years to rebuild," Kokoity said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	12	1518	Four parties are competing for the 34 seats in the parliament, but the central election commission has barred the only two parties not loyal to Kokoity. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	13	1680	Opposition activities said voting would not make a difference. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	14	1743	"I plan to sit at home. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	15	1767	There's nothing we can do," said Alan Gassiyev, an opposition leader, calling the polls "completely illegal."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	18	2246	But despite the slow pace of reconstruction in the republic many praise Kokoity for his leadership during the August conflict. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	19	2382	"Kokoity has done a lot for the people of South Ossetia, he's fought 20 years for this country," Angela Tedeyeva, a 32-year-old kindergarden teacher, said as she cast her ballot. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	20	2570	"If people are happy with him, they will vote for him again," she said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	21	2651	Georgia ridiculed the vote, with the country's reintegration minister Temur Iakobashvili saying the elections were "nothing but clownery, a farce and a redistribution of a criminal power." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	22	2849	Kokoity insists the elections were in strict accordance with law, saying the polls were "a maturity test for the small independent state." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	23	2997	He said the large number of voters at the polling stations was proof that the vote was deemed "genuine" by people. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	24	3121	Eighty-eight polling stations have been set up for the region's 50,000 residents as well as additional sites in Russia for expatriates and refugees from the fighting. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	25	3297	Kokoity's critics are concerned that the high number of polling stations placed in the villages which were used to be populated by ethnic Georgians and which are now nearly empty will be used to falsify the election results. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	26	3531	Kokoity -- who built connections in Moscow working as a trade official for the rebel region when it was known as a highway for smuggling in the early 1990s -- has rejected accusations against him as Georgian propaganda. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	27	3760	But as the looming political scandal in the region threatens to become an embarrassment for Moscow, there are signs that the Kremlin is scaling back its support for the South Ossetian leader. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	28	3961	Sergey Naryshkin, the head of the Russian presidential administration, said on Russian television this month that South Ossetia should not mend the existing term limits in its constitution. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	29	4160	Moscow and Tbilisi fought a brief but intense war last August over the region, which had enjoyed de facto independence since the early 1990s thanks to tacit Russian support. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	30	4343	Following the conflict Russia formally recognised the region as independent, a move followed only by Nicaragua.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	0	58	Activists rally in Singapore to demand Aung San Suu Kyi release 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	1	198	More than 100 people rallied in Singapore late Sunday as part of a regional effort by civil rights groups to press Myanmar's military rulers to release democracy icon Aung San Suu Kyi. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	2	392	The yellow-clad demonstrators observed a minute of silence and released yellow balloons bearing good wishes for the pro-democracy leader during their gathering at a park designated as Singapore's free-speech corner. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	3	617	Similar rallies were also held simultaneously in Indonesia, the Philippines, Malaysia, Cambodia and Thailand, organisers said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	4	753	Aung San Suu Kyi has spent 13 of the last 19 years in detention, mostly at her crumbling lakeside mansion after the junta refused to honour elections won by her political party in 1990. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	5	948	The Nobel Peace Prize winner was moved to Yangon's notorious Insein prison and charged on May 14 for allegedly breaching the terms of her house arrest after John Yettaw, 53-year-old Mormon and former US military veteran, swam to her home and stayed there for two nights. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	6	1228	On Sunday, Myanmar's deputy defence minister Major General Aye Myint told a regional security forum in Singapore that Aung San Suu Kyi had "covered up" the truth by failing to report Yettaw’s visit.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	8	1536	"It’s devastating that they are alluding to this collusion between her and Yettaw. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	9	1619	They need to look at their own security lapses," Mathi told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	10	1693	"It is my hope that this event will be the beginning of concerted efforts by the people of ASEAN to write to their governments and lobby for her release," she said, referring to the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	11	1924	Wunna, a Myanmar citizen working in Singapore, said the Myanmar junta was "trying to find an excuse" to continue detaining Aung San Suu Kyi.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	0	58	Israel fumes over US settlement demands 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	1	174	Israel refused on Sunday to bow to US calls for a freeze of all settlement activity in the occupied West Bank, as it fumed over the "unfair" demands that have raised tensions between the key allies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	2	382	"I want to say in a crystal clear manner that the current Israeli government will not accept in any fashion that legal settlement activity be frozen," said Transport Minister Yisrael Katz, a close ally of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	3	631	The premier also held firm on Israel's controversial blockade of Hamas-run Gaza Strip, warning that the Islamists were rearming and that the ceasefire that ended a 22-day war on January 18 remained very fragile. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	4	852	Netanyahu did not himself address the settlements issue during the weekly cabinet meeting, but Katz's fighting words were echoed by other members of the largely right-wing cabinet, including from its most liberal party, Labour. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	5	1089	A senior Israeli official complained that Washington under President Barack Obama -- who has vowed to pursue Middle East peace talks as part of a changed approach to the region -- was placing unfair demands on the Jewish state. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	6	1326	"The Americans have demanded almost nothing from the Palestinians but are asking Israel to take steps that are a real sacrifice. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	7	1455	These demands are unfair," he told AFP on condition of anonymity. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	8	1530	"The Palestinians are taking a passive approach. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	9	1579	They're not even ready to meet the Israeli side and Abu Mazen (Palestinian president Mahmud Abbas) wants the Americans to do all the work," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	10	1737	Abbas, who met Obama last week 10 days after the US president met Netanyahu, has vowed that that he will not resume talks unless Israel freezes settlements in the occupied West Bank. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	11	1929	The Obama administration has demanded that Israel stop all its activity in the settlements, including so-called natural growth construction that allows for building to accommodate a rising population. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	12	2139	The unusually blunt talk over one of the top stumbling points in the stalled Middle East peace process has raised alarm bells that the new US president could put pressure on Israel as part of his new approach to the Muslim world. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	13	2378	"This is an unjustifiable demand that the government and the public do not accept," said Interior Minister Eli Yishai of the ultra-Orthodox Shas party. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	14	2539	Social Affairs Minister Isaac Herzog of the centre-left Labour party, the most liberal in Netanyahu's government, said that "one has to understand that there are various statuses within the settlements" and "saying that the picture is black and white or write or wrong is wrong." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	15	2828	More than 280,000 Israelis live in settlements dotted throughout the West Bank, which Israel captured in the 1967 war. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	16	2956	Although the international community considers all settlements to be illegal, Israel makes a distinction between those built with the state's blessing and outposts constructed without authorisation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	17	3164	Netanyahu has said he would dismantle outposts, but that it made "no sense" to ask for a complete freeze of construction. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	18	3295	Israeli officials have also complained that Obama's administration has yet to say it will honour commitments in a letter that then US president George W. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	19	3449	Bush sent to then Israeli premier Ariel Sharon in 2004. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	20	3514	Bush said that given the existence of major settlement blocs in the West Bank it was "unrealistic" to expect Israel to fully withdraw from the territory as part of a final peace deal. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	21	3707	Aside from the settlements, there is stark disagreement between Washington and Israel over creating a Palestinian state, with Obama repeatedly saying he was committed to the principle and Netanyahu so far refusing to endorse it in public. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	22	3955	Obama is due in Saudi Arabia and Egypt this week in a bid to reach out to Muslims and end the deep mistrust of the United States felt across much of the Islamic world. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	23	4132	Netanyahu on Sunday also held firm on maintaining the blockade of Gaza, saying that "we do not want to strengthen Hamas" by allowing the Islamist group to rebuild its defences. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	0	58	Israeli FM to Russia, Belarus 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	1	164	Israeli Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman leaves for his first official visits to Russia and Belarus on Monday to discuss Iran and bilateral issues, his ministry said in a statement. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	2	357	In Moscow, Lieberman, a Russian-speaking Soviet emigrant, will meet Russian President Dmitry Medvedev, Prime Minister Vladimir Putin, counterpart Sergei Lavrov and heads of the Jewish community. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	3	561	He will discuss "political developments and regional threats with his hosts" as well as bilateral relations, said the statement. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	4	699	Topping the agenda for the visit is the issue of Iran's controversial nuclear programme, a "severe geopolitical threat to Israel and the entire region," it said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	5	870	Russia is helping build the first nuclear reactor in the Islamic Republic, which Israel considers its arch-enemy after repeated statements by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad calling for the Jewish state to be "wiped off the map." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	6	1107	Widely considered to be the Middle East's sole if undeclared nuclear power, Israel along with main ally Washington suspects Iran of trying to develop atomic weapons under the guise of a civilian nuclear programme, a charge Tehran has repeatedly denied. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	7	1369	Moscow is seeking a greater role in the Middle East and a Russian foreign ministry spokesman said on Friday that Russia hopes Lieberman's visit will boost the country's hopes of hosting a Middle East peace conference this year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	8	1606	The statement from Lieberman's ministry made no mention of the conference idea but Israel has so far been unenthusiastic. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	9	1737	Israel is unhappy about Russia's contacts with the Islamist Hamas movement ruling the Gaza Strip, an Iranian-backed group pledged to the destruction of the Jewish state. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	10	1916	Russia is the only member of the Quartet -- the European Union, the United Nations and the United States -- to be formally on speaking terms with Hamas, classified as a terrorist group by the EU, Israel and the US. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	11	2140	During his trip to Damascus a week ago, Lavrov met with Hamas supremo Khaled Meshaal, telling the Vesti-24 channel later that "we felt a more realistic assessment of the situation" following the talks with the exiled leader. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	12	2374	Lavrov also reiterated that Moscow wanted to see Israel lift a blockade it slapped on Gaza after Hamas assumed power there in June 2007, saying "we hope that we can push toward its removal in the foreseeable future." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	13	2600	At the time, Israel said it was said it was "deeply disappointed" by the meeting. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	14	2691	Following his stay in Russia, Lieberman will travel to Belarus where he will meet President Alexander Lukashenko and Foreign Minister Sergei Martynov on Thursday in Minsk. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	15	2872	It will mark Lieberman's first trip to Russia or Belarus since he was sworn in as foreign minister along with the rest of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's largely right-wing government on March 31. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	16	3082	Lieberman emigrated from Soviet Moldova to Israel in 1978. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	0	58	Tennis: Murray, Gonzalez to clash in French Open quarter-finals 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	1	194	Andy Murray reached his first French Open quarter-final on Sunday where he will face big-hitting Fernando Gonazalez who almost missed Roland Garros due to freak injury caused by signing autographs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	2	401	Third seed Murray became only the third British man in the Open era to reach the last eight here with a convincing 7-5, 7-6 (7/4), 6-1 win over Croatia's Marin Cilic. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	3	577	The ever-improving 22-year-old, with former two-time Roland Garros finalist Alex Corretja helping hone his claycourt game, looked in impressive physical condition with a series of long, punishing rallies eventually telling on the 13th seeded Cilic, the youngest man left in the draw. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	4	870	Cilic, who came into the fourth round having lost the fewest number of games of any player in the last 16, was wilting by the time he slipped 0-3 down in the third set. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	5	1048	He needed treatment on his left leg after falling awkwardly before Murray went on to secure a convincing victory in the seventh game. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	6	1191	Chilean 13th seed Gonzalez revealed how an injury signing autographs almost shattered his French Open dreams. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	7	1310	The 28-year-old, who outgunned Romania's Victor Hanescu 6-2, 6-4, 6-2 to reach the Roland Garros quarter-finals for the third time, injured his ankle while signing photos and tennis balls for fans at the Rome Masters in April. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	8	1546	As a result, he spent a month on the sidelines. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	9	1603	"I was signing autographs and someone called me from the other side of the court and when I ran over to them, I twisted my ankle," said Gonzalez. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	10	1758	"I think I only managed to sign two and then I had to go back to the locker room because my ankle was so painful." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	11	1882	The freak accident meant Gonzalez had to skip the rest of the claycourt season to recover in time for the French Open. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	12	2010	But despite the Rome scare, he believes he is now playing some of the best tennis of his 10-year career. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	13	2124	"I think on average I am playing my best," said Gonzalez who made the semi- finals in Rome where he was defeated by Rafael Nadal before being completely finished off by his injury. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	14	2314	"I have played at a good level almost in every match. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	15	2368	I enjoy going onto the courts and into practice although as I am getting older I tend to practice less but with more intensity." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	16	2506	Later Sunday, defending champion and top seed Rafael Nadal tackles Sweden's Robin Soderling for a place in the last eight. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	17	2638	Nadal beat Soderling for the loss off just one game in Rome last month. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	18	2719	In the day's other last 16 tie, Russian 10th seed Nikolay Davydenko, twice a semi-finalist, faces Spanish eighth seed Fernando Verdasco who is looking for a first quarter-final place.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	0	58	Rights group slams Niger's 'institutional coup' 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	1	178	African rights campaigners on Sunday condemned Niger's president Mamadou Tandja over his planned referendum on whether to extending his legal term of office, describing it as "an institutional coup". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	2	387	The international community should put pressure on the president and if necessary apply sanctions, said Alioune Tine, head of African Defence for Human Rights (RADDHO) in comments broadcast on Radio France Internationale. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	3	618	"In fact this is an institutional coup," said Tine. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	4	670	"This is the start of a new chapter of political instability in Niger," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	5	761	"The international community needs to react, as in all coups, initially by negotiating," said Tine. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	6	870	"And if he (Tandja) does not accept, sanctions need to be imposed." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	7	947	In a broadcast address to the nation on Friday night, Tandja, 71, said he planned to go ahead with a referendum on a new constitution enabling him to stay in power after the normal end of his second five-year term. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	8	1171	He spoke only days after the country's highest court, the Constitutional Court, ruled against such a referendum on Monday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	9	1303	Article 49 of the current constitution, which authorises the president to call a referendum on certain issues, could not serve as a basis for changing the constitution, it said in its ruling. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	10	1504	The day after the court's ruling Tandja dissolved parliament. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	11	1575	Tandja, whose tenure should end 22 December, gave no date for the referendum. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	12	1662	Washingon expressed its concern on Saturday, a statement from the State Department warning that it could be "a setback for democracy". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	13	1806	Canada also asked the Niger authorities to "respect the spirit and the letter" of its constitution.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	0	58	Over 40 injured in protests over Kashmiri women's deaths 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	1	197	More than 40 people have been wounded in two days of clashes between Indian police and Kashmiris demonstrating over the recent deaths of two young Muslim women, police said Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	2	387	Police said they have launched an investigation into the "mystery deaths" of the women, aged 17 and 22. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	3	491	Their families have accused Indian security forces of abducting, raping and subsequently killing them. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	4	603	Angry demonstrators on Sunday hurled stones at riot police and paramilitary forces, who retaliated by firing teargas shells and charging at them with batons. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	5	770	"Over 40 people, including several policemen, have been wounded in two days of clashes between police and protesters," a Muslim police officer said, requesting not to be named. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	6	956	Protesters ransacked a government hospital and a number of other government buildings after the bodies of the women, who were related, were found on Saturday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	7	1124	They were fished out from a shallow stream in Shopian town about 50 kilometres (31 miles) south of the summer capital Srinagar. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	8	1261	Their families said the bodies had marks of violence and their clothes were torn. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	9	1352	An autopsy report will be available on Monday, a police statement said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	10	1433	Indian security forces battling militancy in Kashmir have frequently been accused of committing human rights violations in the scenic Himalayan region. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	11	1585	Officials say they investigate all the cases and punish those found guilty. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	12	1670	Kashmir is in the grip of a nearly 20-year insurgency against Indian rule that has so far left more than 47,000 people dead by official count. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	13	1822	However, violence has dropped sharply since India and Pakistan started a peace process in January 2004 to resolve pending disputes, including Kashmir, which is divided between the two countries but claimed in full by both. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	14	2054	Senior Kashmir minister Ali Sagar said those involved in the two women's killings will be "given exemplary punishment."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	16	2334	Meanwhile, a policeman and an Indian trooper were killed by militants in two separate strikes in northern Kashmir's Baramulla district on Sunday, a police statement said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0210	17	2514	Rebels also made an unsuccessful attempt on the life of a lesser-known pro-India leader, Feroz Malik, the police said, without giving further details.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0213	0	58	Cuba agrees to resume talks with US on migration, mail: US 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0213	1	194	Cuba has agreed to resume talks with the United States on migration and direct mail, a US official said here Sunday, as tense ties continue to thaw under President Barack Obama's administration. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0213	2	398	The announcement came as US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton prepared to travel to the Organization of American States general assembly in Honduras, where Washington and its southern neighbors are caught in a row over the pace of normalization with Cuba. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0213	3	664	The Cuban government informed Washington on Saturday that it "would like to resume migration talks.... 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0213	4	767	(and) engage in talks on direct mail service," the senior State Department official told reporters on the condition of anonymity. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0213	5	906	But he said the two governments still have to decide on a time and place. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0213	6	989	US officials said May 23 that the Obama administration had proposed to resume the discussions on the thorny issue, which had been conducted every two years until they were suspended in 2003 by former president George W. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0213	7	1209	Bush. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0213	8	1224	The official called the moves a "very positive development and step forward" as the Obama administration pursues engagement with Cuba, which has been under a decades-old US embargo. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0213	9	1415	The official said the Cubans "also indicated they would like to explore areas of additional dialogue," such as in the area of counternarcotics, counter terrorism, hurricane and disaster preparedness response.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0214	0	58	Tennis: Murray reaches French Open quarter-finals 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0214	1	180	Andy Murray became only the third British man in the Open era to reach the quarter-finals of Roland Garros on Sunday with a 7-5, 7-6 (7/4), 6-1 win over Croatia's Marin Cilic. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0214	2	365	The third-seeded Briton will now tackle three-time quarter-finalist Fernando Gonzalez, the Chilean 12th seed, for a place in the semi-finals. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0214	3	516	Ever-improving Murray, 22, has now won four successive matches on clay for the first time in his career and he looked impressive on Sunday with his physical fitness proving crucial in a tie of long, punishing rallies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0214	4	743	He broke Cilic, whom he had beaten twice in their two previous meetings, in the opening game and although the tall Croatian hit back immediately, Murray nipped ahead again in the 11th game on his way to taking the opener 7-5. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0214	5	978	Breaks were traded again in the seventh and eighth games of the second before Murray's greater experience told in the tiebreak. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0214	6	1115	Murray was soon a break to the good in the third set against the 20-year-old Cilic, the youngest player left in the men's draw, whose miserable afternoon got worse when he needed treatment to his left leg at 0-3 after falling awkwardly. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0214	7	1361	The Scotsman, with a claycourt game honed by the help of former two-time French Open runner-up Alex Corretja, was soon 4-0 ahead over the wilting Croatian. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0214	8	1526	Cilic, who came into the fourth round having lost the fewest number of games of any player in the last 16, pulled one break back, surrendered it to trail 1-5 before Murray secured a convincing victory in the seventh game.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	0	58	Europe's desperate bid to bring out voters 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	1	176	European leaders on Sunday stepped up a desperate battle to persuade people to vote for the EU parliament this week, but the campaign has opened up new political divisions across the continent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	2	379	With polls indicating a record low turnout for the June 4-7 election, French President Nicolas Sarkozy and German Chancellor Angela Merkel issued a joint plea to voters, saying a strong parliament was essential to confront the economic crisis. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	3	632	The two leaders said they want "a strong Europe that protects" its people and called for "all Europeans to vote" in the statement, published by the Journal du Dimanche newspaper in France and Die Welt am Sonntag in Germany. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	4	865	A "strong Europe does not necessarily mean more powers for the European Union, even more European legislation or even more financial means," said Merkel and Sarkozy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	5	1040	First steps "to assure real European regulation in the financial sector, based on coordination and cooperation between regulators" should be taken at the next EU summit in June, they said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	6	1238	"For speculative funds, tax havens, payment for executives and financial traders, we want an exemplary Europe," they added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	7	1371	The pair also gave strong backing to the Lisbon reform treaty, intended to streamline EU decision-making but deadlocked by Ireland's rejection in a referendum last year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	8	1550	"Europe must play a leading role in the world. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	9	1597	For that, it must have efficient institutions. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	10	1644	That is why we need the Lisbon Treaty," they said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	11	1704	Merkel and Sarkozy also reaffirmed opposition to Turkey joining the EU, without naming the country. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	12	1804	"To be able to act, the EU needs frontiers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	13	1848	Unlimited enlargement is not possible." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	14	1897	The joint statement highlighted fears that the vote for the 736 member European assembly could prove a new embarrassment for the 27-nation European Union, after a record 45 percent abstention at the last election in 2004. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	15	2128	In France, a poll for the Le Parisien newspaper Sunday suggested that 55 percent of the nation's would not bother going to the polls. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	16	2262	In Britain, Poland and Romania, fewer than one in three plan to vote, according to recent surveys. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	17	2370	In Spain, which has benefited enormously from EU development funds, political analysts expect turnout of 40 percent at best. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	18	2495	Portugal expects a record abstention rate. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	19	2547	The stakes are higher now, however, as the European Parliament -- the only directly elected EU institution -- will have a bigger voice in decisions that affect 500 million Europeans if the Lisbon treaty comes into force. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	20	2777	"A lot of voters don't understand what the European Parliament does," said Philip White, senior research fellow at the Centre for European Reform think- tank in London. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	21	2955	"You're not voting to keep a government in office or kick it out. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	22	3021	The stakes can seem a little bit less clear than they are in national elections." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	23	3112	But in many countries the EU vote will be a test of the national governments in power, with far-right and left-wing parties expected to benefit from protest votes and low turnouts in some member states. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	24	3324	In Britain, where euroscepticism runs deep, the governing Labour Party is expected to garner only 16 to 17 percent of the vote, putting it in third place against the rival Conservatives and Liberal Democrats, weekend polls in the Times and Sunday Telegraph suggested. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	25	3601	Turnout at European elections in Britain is usually low -- in the last polls in 2004, it was just 38 percent, and this time, fringe parties like the anti-EU UK Independence Party and the far-right British National Party are expected to benefit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	26	3855	An Economist magazine/YouGov poll last week found that only 31 percent of Britons think its membership of the European Union is a good thing, compared to 37 percent who think it is bad. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	27	4050	The leader of the main opposition Conservatives, David Cameron, has opened up new divisions in Europe by saying he would withdraw his party from the main centre-right bloc in the EU parliament, the European People's Party (EPP), and join a new eurosceptic alliance with Czech and Polish parties. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	28	4355	The EPP is still expected to remain the biggest single party in the parliament, which already has a key role approving the EU budget and passing laws on a wide range of issues. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	29	4541	The parliament will also endorse the new president of the European Commission after a nomination is made by the EU summit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	30	4664	Jose Manuel Barroso, the conservative former Portuguese prime minister, is widely expected to get a second term.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0217	1	167	Italy's already treacherous tour to Australia and New Zealand has been hit by the withdrawals of experienced prop Martin Castrogiovanni, scrum-half Simon Picone and full-back Andrea Marcato.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0217	3	540	The absences will hit a squad that is already without full-back Andrea Masi and hooker Carlo Festuccia as the Metro Racing pair are from the Abruzzo region that was badly hit by an earthquake in April and they have decided to stay with their families.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0220	2	358	The 46-year-old businessman is reported by the BBC to be willing to sell the club for only 80million pounds as opposed to the 135million he paid in 2006. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0220	3	521	Ashley, a Londoner who has tried to conjure up favour with the Newcastle fans by wearing Newcastle team shirts and drinking pints of beer among the spectators, confessed to the Sunday Times that he couldn't wait to leave. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0220	4	752	"It's been catastrophic for everybody. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0220	5	791	I've lost my money and made terrible decisions," he told the Sunday Times. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0220	6	875	"Now I want to sell as soon as I can. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0220	7	913	I am genuinely sorry for everybody for what has happened."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0220	9	1119	"I never said I was an expert in football clubs," Ashley added.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0220	11	1278	"I put my money into it and I tried my best, but I accept my best was woefully short. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0220	12	1373	"Seeing Newcastle relegated has been a catastrophe for us all.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	0	58	Iraq's Kurdish region to export oil for first time 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	1	187	Iraq's self-ruled Kurdish region will begin exporting crude oil for the first time on Monday, piping up to 90,000 bpd to its neighbours, officials said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	2	349	Companies chosen by the regional government will pump oil from two Kurdish fields via an Iraqi pipeline to Turkey with the consent of Baghdad in a step that could pave the way to ending bitter domestic feuds over Iraq's oil wealth. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	3	590	Initial exports will be around 40,000 barrels per day from the Taq Taq field in the province of Arbil and another 50,000 bpd from the Tawke field in Dohuk, company officials told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	4	783	"Piping of the oil will start Monday morning from the Taq Taq field, pumping it from seven wells," said Mohammed Okotan, director of the Taq Taq project for Turkey's Genel Enerji, which is partnered with Calgary-based Addax Petroleum. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	5	1027	"We will try to reach 60,000 barrels a day by the end of this year," said Okotan, adding that the project aims to double exports in two years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	6	1179	"The quality of the crude is excellent," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	7	1238	At the Tawke field, northwest of Taq Taq, Norwegian oil firm DNO will also start pumping oil for export on Monday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	8	1362	"We'll start with 50,000 bpd and we'll see how this operation goes and if we can increase it," said DNO director of operations Jon Sargent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	9	1511	Disagreements over oil rights, especially between Baghdad and the Kurdish government, have held up exploitation of much of Iraq's massive reserves as well as long-delayed hydrocarbons legislation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	10	1717	Terms of the Taq Taq deal are for Baghdad to receive 88 percent of revenues. of which the Kurd region will get back 17 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	11	1845	Genel Enerji and Addax will share 12 percent, Okotan told reporters. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	12	1923	Executives from DNO refused to provide revenue sharing figures, although one DNO official confided that the terms are quite similar to those in the Tawke field. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	13	2093	Iraq is in dire need of revenue to rebuild its shattered economy, especially after oil prices fell from a peak of 147 dollars a barrel last July to a current level just above 60 dollars, putting huge pressure on Iraq's budget. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	14	2329	The nation derives more than 90 percent of its revenues from the energy sector. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	15	2418	Iraq hopes to be able to pump six million barrels per day, up from its current stated output of around 2.2 million, within the next four to five years as new projects come online. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	16	2607	The conflict-ravaged country has the world's third largest proven reserves of oil, with more than 115 billion barrels, behind only Saudi Arabia and Iran.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	1	193	Pakistan's defence secretary said Sunday that a month-long offensive to crush Taliban fighters in the northwest could end within days, as fierce fighting spilled into a nearby tribal area. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	2	391	Swat valley's main town Mingora is back in government hands, the military announced late Saturday, and security officials said they were now pursuing the top leadership of the hardline Taliban movement into the nearby mountains. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	3	629	Secretary of Defence Syed Athar Ali told a security forum in Singapore that three targeted northwest districts were almost clear of Taliban rebels.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	5	886	"Only five to ten percent of the job is remaining and hopefully within the next two to three days these pockets of resistance will be cleared." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	6	1039	The army remains locked in battle in some areas, but the fall of Mingora was a critical milestone in an offensive launched after the Taliban thrust to within 100 kilometres (60 miles) of Islamabad in April. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	7	1255	Pakistan's military also reported that 25 militants and seven soldiers were killed in clashes in South Waziristan near the Afghan border, a bolt-hole for Taliban and Al-Qaeda-linked militants south of the current army bombardment.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	9	1611	The attack was repulsed successfully, inflicting heavy casualties on militants," it said in a statement. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	10	1725	Fifteen militants and three soldiers died in the clash in Spinkai Raghzai, while elsewhere in the semi-autonomous tribal area 10 insurgents and four troops including a lieutenant died when rebels attacked a military convoy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	11	1958	Civilians have started fleeing the area fearing a fresh military onslaught, but the army has denied an imminent assault on Waziristan, where militants branded by Washington as the greatest terror threat to the West are holed up. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	12	2196	The United States, which is firmly backing the current military drive, had warned that the rebels threaten Pakistan's very existence. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	13	2339	Officials have said that lower-ranking Taliban leaders had been killed but it was harder to get to the top leaders, who had a network of hardcore militants around them and had slipped into the rugged mountain terrain. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	14	2566	"They will be eliminated wherever we find them," said one military official, who did not wish to be named as he was not authorised to speak to the media, adding: "We believe that they are somewhere in the mountains."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	16	2995	Fazlullah led thousands of supporters in a campaign that has beheaded opponents, burned schools and fought government troops since November 2007. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	17	3150	The government has also offered rewards for 21 rebel chiefs -- wanted dead or alive -- from Swat. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0257	18	3248	The military claims to have killed 1,244 militants since the offensive began, although the numbers are impossible to verify.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0281	15	2761	Although the international community considers all settlements illegal, Israel makes a distinction between those that were built with the state's blessing and outposts, those constructed without authorisation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0281	16	2980	Netanyahu has said he would dismantle outposts, but that it made "no sense" to ask for a complete freeze to construction.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0281	18	3265	Bush sent to then Israeli premier Ariel Sharon in 2004.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0281	21	3661	"That can only raise concerns over future arrangements."
