AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	1	177	Turks covet religion and are deeply suspicious of the West, but believe radical Islam poses threats to their country and the world, according to a poll published Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	2	356	An overwhelming majority of poll respondents -- 76 and 86 percent respectively -- believe the European Union and the United States aim to divide their country, Milliyet newspaper reported. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	3	554	Turkey is seeking to join the EU and the United States is among the country's NATO allies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	4	654	The survey, conducted by Istanbul's Bahcesehir University among 1,715 people in April and May, found that 62 percent see religion as their top value, followed by secularism and democracy at 16 and 13 percent respectively. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	5	885	Sixty-two percent said it was appropriate for Muslim women to cover their heads outside home, while 58 percent considered it a "sin" for women to wear bathsuits at the beach, Milliyet reported. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	6	1088	Seventy-two percent said they would not wish to have alcohol-consuming neighbours. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	7	1180	Some 66 percent said they would not welcome non-religious neighbours and 67 percent said the same for unmarried couples living together, Milliyet reported. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	8	1345	The poll found that 64 percent do not wish to live next door to a Jew, 52 percent to a Christian, 42 percent to an American and 26 percent to anyone of a different ethnicity or race. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	9	1537	But despite their conservative inclinations, the majority also expressed fears over radical Islam and attacks on democracy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	10	1670	Sixty-nine percent said extremist Islamist movements pose either a "great" or a "certain" threat to Turkey, and a slightly smaller majority believed so for the world. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	11	1846	About 80 percent said "anti-democratic actions and thoughts" are a threat for Turkey. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	0	58	Football: Bordeaux's champion vintage ripens with Blanc 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	1	186	Bordeaux, which produces an estimated 700 million bottles of wine each year, may be best known in gastronomic circles for its distinct clarets. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	2	339	But in the world of French football this year's top vintage is a Blanc. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	3	420	In leading Bordeaux to the French league title for the first time in a decade Laurent Blanc has pulled off a double coup. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	4	551	Not only has he taken the Girondins to glory in only his second season as a coach but the 43-year-old from Ales has also managed to cure a bout of nationwide yawning stretching back to 2002. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	5	751	That year, Lyon won their first ever league title after some near misses and romped past all-comers for the next six years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	6	884	But this year was no one horse race, with Blanc's men landing the crown after a final-day win over relegated Caen gave them 80 points from 38 matches to 77 for Marseille and 71 for Lyon, who next season will have to play in the Champions League qualifiers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	7	1150	"I am really delighted," said Blanc, who pinpointed the win over Lyon five weeks ago as the moment he felt his men were destined to end up as top dogs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	8	1311	"Last year we lost both matches to Lyon, our direct rivals, even if maybe we didn't deserve to. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	9	1407	Then, when Marseille lost to Lyon, that opened the way up for us," noted Blanc, a mainstay of the French side which won the 1998 World Cup and Euro 2000. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	10	1570	Blanc, who suggested it would be very difficult to replicate Lyon's long run of titles, said rigorous hard work in training over the winter had been key. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	11	1733	"We really put in some physical grind in January. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	12	1783	What also helped was that we only really realised quite late in the day just what a great run we were on, so we were under less pressure. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	13	1921	And mentally we were very strong - several times we turned things around right at the death when things weren't going well." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	14	2055	Two defeats in their first four games saw Bordeaux make not the brightest of starts and by the end of September they had eight points to make up on Lyon, who retained the margin going into December. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	15	2263	A pre-Christmas purple patch saw Bordeaux close to within three points but draws against struggling Grenoble and Saint Etienne held up progress as Marseille soared into top spot. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	16	2451	By April, Lyon were fading, their confidence dented by yet another failure to impress in Europe as Barcelona dumped them easily in the Champions League second phase, leaving Bordeaux and Marseille to scrap it out. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	17	2674	Lyon then ultimately did Bordeaux a decisive favour with a May 17 win at Marseille's seething Stade Velodrome to prepare the coronation which came with Saturday's denouement, Yoan Gouffran securing the title after a club record 11th consecutive league win. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	18	2940	Gilding Bordeaux's lily was a League Cup win in April while a further bonus was last week's signing up of star playmaker Yoann Gourcuff, who had only been on loan from AC Milan and who has been the French league's shining star this term. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	19	3187	But now they will be judged on whether they can do what Lyon have consistently failed to do - make a good impression in the Champions League. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	20	3338	Lyon have never made it past the quarter-finals while 1993 winners Marseille remain the only French side to lift the European Cup. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	21	3478	Despite his relative touchline inexperience going into that challenge, Blanc will take heart from the success of Barcelona's 38-year-old Pep Guardiola, who outfoxed Sir Alex Ferguson to land the trophy in his debut season as a coach. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	22	3721	For Bordeaux, triumphing in Europe will demand a different, more elastic mentality from that which suffices for domestic fare and they will be only too aware the transition has traditionally proved awkward for French clubs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	23	3954	That might be down to cultural issues for, as any Frenchman knows, the first course is normally washed down with a glass of rouge. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	24	4094	But with Blanc's coaching genius out of the bottle, Bordeaux are now eying dessert. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	25	4187	That would normally mean sampling any one of a host of the south west's finest vins blancs - although lifting the Champions League would surely demand an 'upgrade' to champagne. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	0	58	Indian court rules schools can bar Sikhs who pluck eyebrows 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	1	194	An Indian court has upheld a decision by a religious body to deny a female student who plucked her eyebrows admission to a Sikh university, media reports said Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	2	370	The ruling said faith-based educational institutions had the right to refuse admission to students who did not meet religious standards, as "maintaining hair unshorn is an essential component of the Sikh religion," according to the Press Trust of India. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	3	633	The policy had been challenged by Gurleen Kaur after she was denied admission to the Sri Guru Ram Das Institute of Medical Sciences and Research in the Sikh holy city of Amritsar. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	4	822	Kaur was excluded on the grounds that she was not a "true Sikh as she was plucking her eyebrows," according to the Times of India. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	5	962	Sikhism requires men and women to keep their hair uncut at all times, and many men sport lengthy beards and wear turbans to cover their long hair. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	6	1118	Kaur's petition was supported by male students who had also been refused admission to the university because they trimmed their beards. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	7	1263	The Punjab and Haryana High Court, which jointly serves both states, said it was "perfectly legitimate" for Sikh organisations to refuse any benefit to members of the community who did not strictly adhere to religious tenets. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	8	1498	Avtar Singh Makkar, the head of the Sikh body which administers the college in Amritsar, said he was happy with the judgment. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	9	1633	"Our stand that unshorn hair is of paramount importance for Sikhs has been vindicated," the Times quoted him as saying. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	10	1762	About 24 million people follow the Sikh faith in India, with a majority of them living in the state of Punjab.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0297	2	371	Media Minister Lakshman Yapa Abeywardena said organisations calling for investigations had "ulterior motives," and dismissed demands for independent probes into the final phase of Sri Lanka's war against Tamil separatists.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0297	4	750	He said the government itself was in the process of assessing the civilian casualties, but gave no figures. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0297	5	867	"Our officials knew how many people were in the (war zone) area and we are taking a tally on the number of people now in the IDP (internally displaced persons) camps," Abeywardena said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0301	0	58	Troops hunt Taliban as Pakistan says victory nears 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0301	1	194	Pakistan's defence secretary said Sunday that a month-long offensive to crush Taliban fighters in the northwest could end within days, as security forces hunted down the militant leadership. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0301	2	394	Swat valley's main town Mingora is back in government hands, the military announced late Saturday, and Syed Athar Ali told a security forum in Singapore that three targeted northwest districts were almost clear of Taliban rebels. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0301	3	633	"Operations in Swat, Buner and adjoining areas have almost met complete success," the secretary of defence said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0301	4	755	"Only five to ten percent job is remaining and hopefully within the next two to three days these pockets of resistance will be cleared." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0301	5	901	The army remains locked in battle in some areas, but the fall of Mingora was a critical milestone in an offensive launched after the Taliban thrust to within 100 kilometres (60 miles) of Islamabad in April. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0301	6	1117	Security officials also reported that 45 militants were killed in fierce fighting in South Waziristan near the Afghan border, a bolt-hole for Taliban and Al-Qaeda-linked militants south of the current army bombardment. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0301	7	1345	Washington, which is firmly backing the military drive, had warned that the rebels threatened Pakistan's very existence and identified the country and Afghanistan as central to its 'war on terror'. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0301	8	1552	"We are trying to target the top leadership of militants and they are constantly being followed," chief military spokesman Major General Athar Abbas said as he announced the Mingora win. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0301	9	1748	Officials said lower-ranking leaders had been killed but it was harder to get to the top leaders, who had a network of hardcore militants around them and had slipped into the rugged mountain terrain. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0301	10	1957	"They will be eliminated wherever we find them," said one military official, who did not wish to be named as he was not authorised to speak to the media, adding: "We believe that they are somewhere in the mountains." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0301	11	2183	Pakistan has slapped a 600,000-dollar price on the head of firebrand Swat Taliban commander Maulana Fazlullah for masterminding the nearly two-year uprising in the valley to enforce sharia law. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0301	12	2386	Fazlullah led thousands of supporters, a mixture of hardcore ideologues and disenfranchised young men, in a brutal campaign that has beheaded opponents, burned scores of schools and fought government troops since November 2007.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0301	14	2730	But as the government ups its campaign to stamp out the militants, fears are growing of a wave of revenge attacks.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0302	2	404	He said the expenses furore was "appalling" and "offends everything that I believe in" as well as promising that every lawmaker would be forced to account for all their expenses from the last four years.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0303	3	586	Doctors said diarrhoea had broken out at an "alarming rate" as inundation and waterlogging in a vast swathe of land close to the world's largest mangrove forest Sundarbans has destroyed supplies of drinking water.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0306	0	58	Vietnam records first swine flu case: ministry 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0306	1	177	Vietnam has recorded its first case of swine flu after a man tested positive for the virus, the health ministry said Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0306	2	311	"It is the first patient of the virus A(H1N1) in Vietnam," ministry spokesman Nguyen Huy Nga told AFP, adding that the case was "confirmed officially by our ministry this morning." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0306	3	501	An initial test at the tropical diseases hospital in southern Ho Chi Minh City was positive, and two follow-up tests at the city's Pasteur Institute confirmed the diagnosis, Phan Van Tu, a doctor with the Institute, told AFP.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0306	5	834	State television reported that the patient returned home early last week from the United States via Hong Kong. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0306	6	954	The World Health Organization (WHO) said it had been formally notified of the case. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0306	7	1047	It said the patient sought medical attention after noticing flu symptoms a day after returning from the United States. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0306	8	1166	Five members of his family have been given medication and placed in isolation, while passengers on the same flight as the man are being tracked down, the WHO said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	0	58	Europe's desperate bid to bring out voters 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	1	176	European leaders on Sunday stepped up a desperate battle to persuade people to vote for the EU parliament this week, but the campaign has opened up new political divisions across the continent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	2	379	With polls indicating a record low turnout for the June 4-7 election, French President Nicolas Sarkozy and German Chancellor Angela Merkel issued a joint plea to voters, saying a strong parliament was essential to confront the economic crisis. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	3	632	The two leaders said they want "a strong Europe that protects" its people and called for "all Europeans to vote" in the statement, published by the Journal du Dimanche newspaper in France and Die Welt am Sonntag in Germany. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	4	865	A "strong Europe does not necessarily mean more powers for the European Union, even more European legislation or even more financial means," said Merkel and Sarkozy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	5	1040	First steps "to assure real European regulation in the financial sector, based on coordination and cooperation between regulators" should be taken at the next EU summit in June, they said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	6	1238	"For speculative funds, tax havens, payment for executives and financial traders, we want an exemplary Europe," they added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	7	1371	The pair also gave strong backing to the Lisbon reform treaty, intended to streamline EU decision-making but deadlocked by Ireland's rejection in a referendum last year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	8	1550	"Europe must play a leading role in the world. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	9	1597	For that, it must have efficient institutions. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	10	1644	That is why we need the Lisbon Treaty," they said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	11	1704	Merkel and Sarkozy also reaffirmed opposition to Turkey joining the EU, without naming the country. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	12	1804	"To be able to act, the EU needs frontiers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	13	1848	Unlimited enlargement is not possible." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	14	1897	The joint statement highlighted fears that the vote for the 736 member European assembly could prove a new embarrassment for the 27-nation European Union, after a record 45 percent abstention at the last election in 2004. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	15	2128	In France, a poll for the Le Parisien newspaper Sunday suggested that 55 percent of the nation's would not bother going to the polls. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	16	2262	In Britain, Poland and Romania, fewer than one in three plan to vote, according to recent surveys. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	17	2370	In Spain, which has benefited enormously from EU development funds, political analysts expect turnout of 40 percent at best. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	18	2495	Portugal expects a record abstention rate. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	19	2547	The stakes are higher now, however, as the European Parliament -- the only directly elected EU institution -- will have a bigger voice in decisions that affect 500 million Europeans if the Lisbon treaty comes into force. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	20	2777	"A lot of voters don't understand what the European Parliament does," said Philip White, senior research fellow at the Centre for European Reform think- tank in London. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	21	2955	"You're not voting to keep a government in office or kick it out. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	22	3021	The stakes can seem a little bit less clear than they are in national elections." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	23	3112	But in many countries the EU vote will be a test of the national governments in power, with far-right and left-wing parties expected to benefit from protest votes and low turnouts in some member states. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	24	3324	In Britain, where euroscepticism runs deep, the governing Labour Party is expected to garner only 16 to 17 percent of the vote, putting it in third place against the rival Conservatives and Liberal Democrats, weekend polls in the Times and Sunday Telegraph suggested. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	25	3601	The leader of the main opposition Conservatives, David Cameron, has opened up new divisions in Europe by saying he would withdraw his party from the main centre-right bloc in the EU parliament, the European People's Party (EPP), and join a new eurosceptic alliance with Czech and Polish parties. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	26	3906	The EPP is still expected to remain the biggest single party in the parliament, which already has a key role approving the EU budget and passing laws on a wide range of issues. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	27	4092	The parliament will also endorse the new president of the European Commission after a nomination is made by the EU summit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	28	4215	Jose Manuel Barroso, the conservative former Portuguese prime minister, is widely expected to get a second term.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	0	58	French physicists claim breakthrough in ultra-fast data access 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	1	193	French physicists said on Sunday they had used ultra-fast lasers that could accelerate storage and retrieval of data on hard discs by up to 100,000 times, pointing the way to a new generation of IT wizardry. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	2	410	The research builds on achievements that earned the 2007 Nobel physics prize for Albert Fert of France and Peter Gruenberg of Germany, who ushered in a revolution in miniaturised storage in the 1990s. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	3	620	Fert and Gruenberg discovered that tiny changes in magnetic fields can yield a large electric output. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	4	731	These differences in turn cause changes in the current in the readout head that scans a hard disk to spot the ones and zeroes in which data is stored. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	5	891	That discovery opened the way to "spintronics", a form of electronics that uses not only electrical charge but also the spin of electrons in individual atoms to provide a more compact, denser storage on hard drives. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	6	1116	But reading and writing data through spintronics has been hampered by the relative slowness of magnetic sensors. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	7	1238	In a study published in the specialist journal Nature Physics, a team led by Jean-Yves Bigot of the Institute of Materials Physics and Chemistry in Strasbourg employed a "femtosecond" laser, using ultra-fast bursts of laser light, to alter electron spin and thus speed up retrieval and storage. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	8	1542	"Our method is called the photonics of spin, because it is photons [particles of light] that modify the state of the electrons' magnetisation" on the storage surface, Bigot told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	9	1734	Data is retrieved with a burst that lasts just a millionth of a billionth of a second, said Bigot. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	10	1842	Femtosecond lasers currently measure around 30 centimetres (12 inches) by 10 centimetres (four inches) which means they are too big for consumer electronics, he cautioned. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	11	2023	Bigot added, though, that their miniaturisation is likely to be achieved over the next decade. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	12	2127	IBM, Hitachi and other corporations are "extremely interested" by the research, Bigot said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	0	58	First genes spotted for testicular cancer 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	1	172	Scientists in Britain said Sunday they had found the first genes that are associated with testicular cancer, the commonest form of cancer for men between the ages of 15 and 45. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	2	358	Telltale variants in chromosomes 5, 6 and 12 are linked with an increased risk of the disease, according to their study, which compared the genetic code of 730 men who had testicular cancer with that of healthy men. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	3	583	Inheriting the basket of three factors boosts the risk of the cancer, called testicular gem cell tumour, by up to fourfold. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	4	716	The study is published online in the journal Nature Genetics. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	5	787	"We have known for some time that men whose father, brothers or sons had testicular cancer are much more likely to get it themselves and we have been searching for this genetic link," said one of the investigators, Elizabeth Rapley of the Institute of Cancer Research, in the southern English county of Surrey. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	6	1107	"We believe there are more (risk factors) still to be found and we are working on identifying the rest." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	7	1221	The three telltales lie near genes that nurture testicular cells which are precursors in sperm development. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	8	1338	Worldwide incidence of testicular cancer is 7.5 cases per 100,000 men, but the rates vary remarkably between countries and according to ancestry, the ICR said in a press release. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	9	1526	Why this is so is unclear. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	10	1553	Inheritance, though, is a well-known risk factor and seems to be far higher than for other cancer types. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	11	1667	Studies have found that the risk to brothers of testicular cancer patients is eight to 10 times higher than the general population, while for fathers of patients, the risk is four to six times higher. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	12	1877	Testicular cancer is 99 percent curable if caught in its early stages, the ICR said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0318	22	3140	"True, I can travel to Nicaragua now, but I don't even have a home to go back to and there's no work there," taxi driver German Zaseyev said sarcastically.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0318	24	3452	Now their only outside link is a 120 kilometre (75 mile) drive to Russia over a winding mountain road often blocked by avalanches throughout the long winter. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0318	25	3619	There is just one factory in South Ossetia that produces building material, a small asphalt plant, but even it is not often working.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0320	2	382	Joined by passers-by of several nationalities, the Green Bird squad -- part of a volunteer movement in Japanese and European cities -- was aiming to encourage residents and visitors alike to keep the French capital tidy.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	0	58	Progress in fighting lung cancer at specialist summit 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	1	195	Cancer specialists, gathered for an annual meeting, are reporting progress in the fight against lung cancer, the most common and deadliest form of cancer, but little progress in treating colorectal cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	2	410	Doctors and researchers at the 45th gathering of the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) -- the world's main cancer conference -- on Saturday learned of two studies showing progress in the battle against lung cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	3	645	The first study showed how the combination of two anti-cancer treatments following standard chemotherapy can slow the advance of lung cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	4	796	Patients treated with a combination of Tarceva, sold by the Swiss drugmaker Roche, and Avastin, a drug by Roche's Genentech unit, saw their cancer growth slow more than a control group treated with Avastin. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	5	1012	More than 750 patients were randomized to receive Avastin and a placebo, or Avastin and Tarceva. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	6	1109	Those in the Tarceva group survived an average of 4.8 months before the cancer started growing again, compared to 3.7 months for the control group, said Vincent Miller, the study's main author. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	7	1312	The numbers translated to a 29 percent reduced risk of disease progression for patients who took a combination of Tarceva and Avastin. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	8	1456	"This is the first study to show that adding erlotinib (Tarceva) to maintenance therapy with bevacizumab (Avastin) delays disease progression in patients who have already received bevacizumab as part of their initial chemotherapy," said Miller. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	9	1710	A second study with 663 patients with advance lung cancer were given the drug Alimta, from US pharmaceutical Eli Lilly, which blocks cell growth. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	10	1865	Preliminary results showed that patients who took the drug lived 26 percent longer compared to a control group that took a placebo: 13.4 months against 10.6 months. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	11	2039	As in the first study, all the patients had already received four standard chemotherapy sessions. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	12	2146	"This study will change the overall standard of care," said Chandra Belani, the deputy director of the Penn State Cancer Institute, as she presented the research. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	13	2318	"Maintenance therapy with Alimta (permetrexed) offers a new paradigm for patients who have advanced lung cancer, because it has a low toxicity and can be given on an ongoing basis over a prolonged period of time to extend patients' lives," she said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	14	2577	However there were few advances to report in the fight against colorectal cancer, the fourth most common in the United States and the second deadliest type of cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	15	2753	Research on 2,710 patients with Phase Three colorectal cancer taking the drug Avastine along with standard chemotherapy treatment showed no difference in the survival rate or the recurrence of the tumor after three and a half years when compared to those not taking the drug. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	16	3038	Another study conducted in Italy among 747 patients with advanced colorectal cancer showed that the drug Eloxatine from the French firm Sanofi did not reduce the size of the tumor when combined with standard treatment used ahead of cancer surgery. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	17	3295	On Sunday, several sessions at the ASCO event, scheduled to end on Tuesday, will focus on the result of clinical tests on female breast and uterus cancer.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0342	18	3328	"Coincidentally, the Ford Foundation was established by secretary Geithner's father," the official said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0342	25	4479	Being the top holder of the bonds, China is the largest creditor to the United States aside from being the world's largest holder of US dollars as a reserve currency, at nearly two trillion dollars.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	0	58	Climate change: 'Bali Road Map' looks for a compass 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	1	182	Gruelling efforts to craft a pact on climate change enter a crucial phase on Monday when the 192-nation UN forum takes its first look at a draft text for negotiations. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	2	359	The 12-day huddle in the German city of Bonn under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) means that, after 18 months of swapping visions, the process will at last get down to the gritty stuff. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	3	578	Little more than six months are left before the "Bali Road Map", launched in Indonesia in 2006, reaches its supposed destination at a Copenhagen summit: an accord that will transform global warming from a monster into a manageable problem. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	4	827	On the table is a small mountain of paper whose notable feature is curly brackets, denoting discord among scores of submissions. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	5	965	Despite the sprawling range of proposals, UNFCCC Executive Secretary Yvo de Boer said he hoped that the draft will be endorsed as a workable basis for talks over the coming months. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	6	1155	"There will be a negotiating text on the table for the first time," he told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	7	1245	"I hope it will be well received, that it will be seen as a balanced representation of the different ideas that countries have come with." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	8	1393	The big goal is to slash emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 compared to 1990 levels. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	9	1490	But that's where consensus largely ends. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	10	1531	Exactly how deep should be the cut be? 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	11	1570	How can it be achieved? 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	12	1594	And who should shoulder the burden? 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	13	1639	In their proposals, many developing countries say rich countries, which bear historical responsibility for today's warming, should take the lead by cutting their emissions by 25-40 percent by 2020. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	14	1846	China has led the charge, demanding a cut of "at least" 40 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	15	1923	But only the European Union (EU), which has set its own reduction of 20 percent by 2020, deepened to 30 percent if other advanced economies play ball, is anywhere near such a figure. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	16	2115	After eight long years of vilification, the United States is now being warmly embraced in the climate arena as Barack Obama bulldozes George W. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	17	2259	Bush's policies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	18	2285	But Washington is also warning that the world cannot expect miracles. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	19	2364	A bill put before Congress would cut US emissions by 17 percent by 2020 over 2005 levels using a cap-and-trade system of the kind Bush loathed. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	20	2517	This approach would translate to a reduction of only four percent compared to the 1990 benchmark, but it would also ratchet up to 83 percent by 2050, the top US climate change negotiator, Todd Stern, said in Paris last week. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	21	2751	"We are jumping as high as the political system will tolerate," said Stern, characterising China's demand of a 40 percent cut by 2020 as "not realistic". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	22	2914	Just as unresolved is what the emerging giant countries should do. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	23	2990	The draft should at least "call for those wealthier, more capable countries to take actions," said Stern's deputy, Jonathan Pershing. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	24	3133	China is now the world's No. 1 polluter, and Brazil and India have also leapt up the emission ranks as their economies have grown. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	25	3273	Yet all refuse binding emissions targets of the kind that apply only to rich countries under the Kyoto Protocol, the UNFCCC treaty to be superseded from 2013 by the Copenhagen accord. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	26	3466	Then there is how to muster finance to help poor countries adapt to the impacts of climate change, and how to transfer clean technology so that they avoid becoming the greenhouse-gas villains of the future. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	27	3682	Keya Chatterjee, deputy director of the climate change programme with the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) said emerging countries were thirsting for the energy switch. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	28	3853	"It's sort of a green arms race where everybody wants to have access to clean- energy industry," she said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	29	3960	"That's a pretty huge change in the negotiations that will affect the dynamics." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	30	4050	Even so, she said, developing countries were suspicious. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	31	4107	"This lack of trust comes from a long tradition of industrialised countries not living up to their obligations." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	32	4229	These are just a few of the many obstacles besetting the Bali Road Map. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	33	4310	The complexity is such that many experts now predict Copenhagen will not be a complete treaty but, at best, a good deal on the main points. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	34	4459	"I think that what we are looking at in Copenhagen is a deal that will lock in some specific emission reductions goals, will create commitments both for investment and adaptation and then... the details will have to be filled in later," said Angela Anderson of the US Climate Action Network (CAN).

AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	1	183	Russian and US negotiators are due to meet in Geneva on Monday for a second round of talks on renewing a key Cold War-era arms reduction deal, a month before their leaders hold a landmark summit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	2	388	Diplomats said the three day meeting on the START treaty would be held behind closed doors at an undisclosed location, mirroring the discretion surrounding the first round in Moscow nearly two weeks ago. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	3	601	"On the details of the negotiation, I think we prefer to keep that in private right now. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	4	690	I think that's just the best way to conduct these kinds of negotiations," US State Department spokesman Ian Kelly said in Washington.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	7	1248	On top of the complex technical issues surrounding the landmark treaty -- which took a decade to reach agreement on the deep cuts in US and Soviet nuclear arsenals after the fall of the Iron Curtain -- the negotiations are also hampered by differing ambitions.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	11	1919	Disarmament expert Jozef Goldblat said the START talks allowed the United States to create a climate "propitious for help with other more complicated subjects" where Washington needs Moscow's support, such as Iran and North Korea's controversial nuclear programmes.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	13	2371	The United States has insisted that the defensive shield is meant to counter an Iranian threat. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	14	2476	But Russia regards the shield, which would partly be based in former eastern bloc countries close to its borders, as a threat to its own security. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	15	2632	"The number one stumbling block is the anti missile shield," said Volk. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	16	2704	"Moscow wants Washington to give up deployment but the Americans are against that." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	17	2797	Russian military analyst Alexander Goltz said the negotiations also helped Moscow recover some of its prestige. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	18	2918	"The Russians are aiming to make the process last as long as possible, because the talks restore their status as a world power," he explained. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	19	3070	Russian officials hailed the "constructive and business-like" atmosphere of the first round, but US delegation chief Rose Gottemoeller warned before the talks even began that the process could be more drawn out than expected. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	20	3305	Goltz played down expectations for the Obama-Medvedev summit because the two sides were too far apart. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0347	21	3417	But veteran disarmament observer Goldblat suggested an elegant way out: a five year extension of START that would give time for negotiations on a "broader" disarmament deal between the world's biggest nuclear powers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	0	58	Major security plan drawn up for Lebanon vote: minister 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	1	187	Lebanon will deploy 50,000 police and soldiers to prevent any outbreak of violence during the June 7 parliamentary election as part of a major security plan, Interior Minister Ziad Baroud has said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	2	394	"We will have 30,000 police and soldiers deployed at polling stations and their vicinity and 20,000 other police and soldiers deployed elsewhere nationwide," Baroud told AFP in an interview. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	3	594	He said the plan takes into account sensitive regions where violence could erupt on election day between members of the current Western-backed ruling majority and supporters of the Hezbollah-led opposition alliance, which is backed by Iran and Syria. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	4	854	Sectarian violence between the two sides left around 100 people dead last May when Hezbollah staged a spectacular takeover of mainly Sunni parts of west Beirut, prompting fears of a new civil war. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	5	1060	Baroud said security measures on election day had taken into account the risk of violence in each of the 26 electoral districts. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	6	1198	"In some districts there is minimal risk and in others it's more serious," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	7	1282	"And it's according to the risk factor that troops will be deployed." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	8	1361	For example, he said there was little likelihood of violence erupting in most of the regions in southern Lebanon where Hezbollah and its allies are assured victory. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	9	1535	However, the situation is expected to be more tense in regions where the vote is set to be tight, including the southern coastal town of Sidon and in the eastern Bekaa valley town of Zahle. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	10	1734	Baroud said he was nonetheless optimistic the vote would proceed smoothly, noting that there had been few security incidents in the run-up to the election. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	11	1899	"Of course, I am anxious ... but the political situation (locally and regionally) is more reassuring than alarming," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	12	2034	"It's up to the country's political factions and every Lebanese man or woman to ensure there is no outbreak of violence." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	13	2165	Baroud, 39, a widely popular minister in the current 30-member national unity government in which Hezbollah is represented, said measures had also been adopted to prevent fraud at the 5,200 polling stations. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	14	2382	The vote this year for the first time is taking place on a single day rather than over a month-long period. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	15	2499	"We have taken anti-fraud measures including placing transparent boxes in polling stations, more secrecy of voting and we have adopted international standards," Baroud said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	16	2682	"Also the indelible ink we will be using will prevent someone from voting twice." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	17	2773	Some 2,200 national observers and 250 international monitors will oversee the vote including from the European Union, the Carter Center, the Arab League and several countries. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	18	2958	The 128 seats in parliament are divided equally between Christians and Muslims. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	19	3047	Baroud said he expected final results to be announced on June 8, barring any major security incidents or fraud. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	20	3168	"I am crossing my fingers on a daily basis," he said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0359	2	364	The party, which also wants to beef up Internet privacy, was founded in January 2006 and quickly attracted members angered by controversial laws adopted in the Scandinavian country that criminalised filesharing and authorised monitoring of emails. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0359	3	621	Its membership shot up after a Stockholm court on April 17 sentenced four Swedes to a year in jail for running one of the world's biggest filesharing sites, The Pirate Bay. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0359	4	803	"When the verdict was announced at 11:00 am, we had 14,711 members," Rick Falkvinge, the 37-year-old founder of the party, told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0359	5	945	"We tripled in a week, becoming the third-biggest party in Sweden in terms of numbers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0359	6	1032	All of a sudden we were everywhere." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0359	7	1078	Opinion polls ahead of the June 7 European parliament elections credit the party with between 5.5 and 7.9 percent of votes, well above the four percent required to win a seat. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0359	8	1263	In the 2006 general election, held eight months after it's creation, the Pirate Party won just 0.6 percent of votes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0359	9	1389	"They have been very lucky because The Pirate Bay verdict came at the same time as the start of the election campaign, but I think The Pirate Party had the potential to grow anyway," a political scientist at Gothenburg University, Ulf Bjereld, told AFP.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0359	15	2420	The typical Pirate Party supporter is a young, male Internet buff.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0359	17	2689	The party garners some 10.5 percent support among male voters, but only 1.5 percent of women. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0359	18	2792	"It's a 'geek' party," admitted Brian Levinsen, a 31-year-old member, attending a recent campaign meeting in Stockholm.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0359	20	3037	"There is always someone (from the party) online, even at 2:00 or 4:00 in the morning," he added.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	0	58	Guide to Europe's four day election marathon 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	1	178	The European Union parliament has long had the image of being a gravy-train but an EU election is no picnic. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	2	296	The voting system is as arcane as the 27-nation EU is widespread. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	3	362	The election for the 736 lawmakers takes four days and there will be weeks of bargaining afterwards to settle the assembly's top jobs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	4	506	Voting starts on Thursday in Britain and the Netherlands. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	5	564	Ireland holds its election on the following day, the Czech Republic on June 5 and 6, and Slovakia Latvia, Malta and Cyprus vote on June 6. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	6	712	France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the other 15 countries in the EU all hold their elections on the Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	7	819	The first reliable forecasts will come out about 2000 GMT on the night of June 7. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	8	910	Each country uses its own preferred voting system. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	9	970	While any EU citizen can stand as a candidate or vote in any EU country where he or she is resident and registered on the electoral list, rules such as the minimum age for voting changes from country to country. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	10	1191	There were 785 deputies in the old assembly. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	11	1236	The Treaty of Nice ordered the cutback but this could be only temporary. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	12	1309	If the Treaty of Lisbon is ever ratified by every member the number will go up again to 754. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	13	1411	Each country's representation is roughly in line with its population. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	14	1481	Malta, the smallest member, has five deputies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	15	1528	Germany, the biggest, has 99. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	16	1558	The other main powers -- Britain, France and Italy -- have 72 each, while Poland and Spain elect 50 each. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	17	1673	One of the big unknowns is how the extra 18 deputies will be shared out, if the Lisbon reform treaty comes into force. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	18	1801	The first meeting of the new assembly will be on July 14-16 in Strasbourg. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	19	1885	It will have to elect a new parliament president to take charge of the assembly for the first half of its five year term. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	20	2016	As the centre-right bloc is expected to gain the upper hand in the election, their candidates, former Polish prime minister Jerzy Buzek, and Italian Euro deputy Mario Mauro, a close ally of Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, are favourites. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	21	2273	One of their first duties will also be to approve the European Commission president nominated by an EU summit at the end of June. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	22	2403	Jose Manuel Barroso, the former Portuguese prime minister, is widely expected to get a second term. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0362	0	58	Europe's desperate bid to bring out voters 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0362	1	176	European leaders on Sunday stepped up a desperate battle to persuade people to vote for the unloved EU parliament this week, but the campaign has opened up new political divisions across the continent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0362	2	387	With polls indicating a record low turnout for the June 4-7 election, French President Nicolas Sarkozy and German Chancellor Angela Merkel issued a joint plea to voters, saying a strong parliament was essential to confront the economic crisis. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0362	3	640	The two said they want "a strong Europe that protects" its people and called for "all Europeans to vote" in the statement, published by the Journal du Dimanche newspaper in France and Die Welt am Sonntag in Germany. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0362	4	865	A "strong Europe does not necessarily mean more powers for the European Union, even more European legislation or even more financial means," said Merkel and Sarkozy who still called for "real European regulation" to tackle the financial crisis. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0362	5	1119	They said first steps "to assure real European regulation in the financial sector, based on coordination and cooperation between regulators" should be taken at the EU summit in June. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0362	6	1311	"For speculative funds, tax havens, payment for executives and financial traders, we want an exemplary Europe," the French and German leaders said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0362	10	1695	That is why we need the Lisbon Treaty," they said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0362	19	2627	In Spain, which has benefited enormously from EU funds, analysts expect turnout of 40 percent at best. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0362	20	2730	Portugal expects a record abstention rate. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0362	21	2782	The stakes are higher now however as the parliament is likely to win a bigger voice in decisions that affect the EU's 500 million population if the Lisbon treaty comes into force.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0369	2	352	The five-day exercise will simulate simultaneous rocket strikes from the Gaza Strip and Lebanon and missile attacks from arch-foes Syria and Iran and test the way rescue services deal with the attacks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0369	3	563	"We will be exercising the doomsday scenario of simultaneous strikes against Israel on all fronts and by different means," defence ministry spokesman Shlomo Dror told AFP last week. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0369	4	754	This will include conventional, chemical and biological strikes against large population centres. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0369	5	852	It will also simulate a wave of Palestinian suicide bombings. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0369	6	923	On Tuesday, when air-raid sirens sound across the country and citizens must scramble to shelters, in some areas within seconds and others within no more than three minutes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0369	7	1105	Exercise Turning Point 3 will also simulate the conduct of rescue and medical services during earthquakes and epidemics. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0369	8	1235	And there will be simulated cabinet meetings in which ministers will weigh their response to such attacks and scenarios. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0369	9	1365	It is the third consecutive year Israel is conducting such an exercise, although this year's drill is the largest-ever. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0369	10	1494	The manoeuvres began in the aftermath of the July-August 2006 war with Lebanon's Hezbollah militia, which revealed major weaknesses in how the Jewish state's homefront dealt with the rocket attacks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0369	11	1702	"The Second Lebanon War revealed that the homefront was not well prepared for war and citizens found it hard to adapt to the special situation," Dror said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	1	184	Indian students rallied in Melbourne on Sunday as Australia scrambled to contain outrage over a wave of attacks that has seen it labelled racist and strained diplomatic relations with New Delhi. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	2	388	What began as a local policing issue in Australia's second largest city has spiralled into a crisis that prompted Prime Minister Kevin Rudd to call his Indian counterpart Manmohan Singh last week to assure him about student safety. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	3	629	The students are demanding action after more than 70 assaults on their peers in a year in Melbourne, including at least four in the past fortnight, and there has been prominent coverage in newspapers here and in India. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	4	857	Pictures from a hospital bed of a comatose Sravan Kumar Theerthala, who was stabbed with a screwdriver by gatecrashers at a party, were splashed across newspapers in India. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	5	1030	A teenager has been charged with attempted murder. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	6	1090	"They were saying, 'Don't touch us you Indians' and 'Indians go home' before they got the screwdriver," said Theerthala's friend, Jayasanka Bagpelli. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	7	1249	Another student, Baljinder Singh, told Australian public radio last week how his attackers laughed as he pleaded with them during a robbery at a Melbourne train station. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	8	1428	"I was saying to them, 'I'm giving you all my money, don't kill me, don't kill me'," said Singh, who was stabbed and left with a six-inch (15-centimetre) wound to his stomach and advised Indians to stay away from Australia. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	9	1661	Indian media have dubbed the attacks "curry bashings", picking up on a term reportedly used by some of the youths behind the violence in Melbourne's western suburbs, where police say 30 percent of assault victims are Indian. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	10	1895	It is a grossly disproportionate figure in a city of almost four million people where the Indian student population numbers less than 50,000. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	11	2046	Police deny any racial element to the attacks, arguing Indian students were often simply in the wrong place at the wrong time as they travelled home late at night with items such as mobile phones and portable MP3 players. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	12	2277	But Indian High Commissioner to Australia Sujatha Singh said last week that racism was playing a part, even if some of the crimes were "opportunistic". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	13	2438	Federation of Indian Students president Amit Menghani, who led the rally of more than a thousand supporters through central Melbourne Sunday, said the police attitude had frustrated many students. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	14	2644	Bagpelli, who attended the rally, added: "It's only because the Indian government is now applying pressure that they are doing anything." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	15	2791	While the attacks are unlikely to result in any permanent damage at a diplomatic level, Canberra is concerned parents in India may prevent their children studying in Australia. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	16	2977	That would threaten the international education sector here, a 15.5 billion dollar (12.2 billion US) a year industry that has attracted more than 90,000 Indians to the country. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	17	3163	More broadly, with headlines such as "Australia, land of racism" running in overseas media, there are also fears Australia's reputation for tolerance is sustaining long-term damage. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	18	3354	A string of government ministers have made statements recently emphasising the country's multi-cultural society and relatively low levels of violence. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	19	3514	"We need to help make sure that the mothers and fathers of all students who come here are assured that Australia is a safe location to come to, that our general crime rates and violence rates are very low," Foreign Minister Stephen Smith told commercial television Sunday.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	21	3926	It sparked a flurry of high-level diplomatic activity and strong public statements from Indian officials that indicated they had run out of patience. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0381	22	4085	"Such attacks cannot be allowed to happen," Singh said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	0	58	Indian author Kamala Das dead at 75 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	1	170	Writer and poet Kamala Das, known for her frank discussion of female sexuality in conservative India, died in hospital on Sunday, the Press Trust of India reported. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	2	335	She was 75. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	3	356	Das died in the western city of Pune after a long illness, PTI said, without specifying the cause of death. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	4	473	Das was born into a family of writers and wrote poems and short stories in English and Malayalam, the language of her southern home state of Kerala. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	5	631	She was one of the first Indian writers to explore sexual themes in her work, and her 1976 autobiography, My Story, was a candid recollection of her own sexual coming of age that was translated into 15 languages. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	6	853	Das converted to Islam in 1999 and took the name Kamala Surayya, but later appeared to regret it, saying "God has no connection with any religion. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	7	1000	There is no respect for women anywhere." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	8	1050	She also dabbled in politics, launching the Lok Seva Party but failing to win a seat in parliament. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	9	1159	Das is survived by two sons.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	0	58	GM bondholders approve debt restructuring deal: report 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	1	190	Ailing General Motors moved closer Sunday to its expected bankruptcy filing as company bondholders approved a  government-sponsored debt for equity deal, The New York Times reported. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	2	382	The bondholders had until 5:00 pm (2100 GMT) Saturday to indicate whether they supported the group's new offer ahead of the once mighty corporation's looming bankruptcy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	3	561	The government's rescue plan for GM could put as much as 72.5 percent of the country's biggest automaker under state ownership. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	4	698	Citing "people briefed on the matter," the newspaper said the bondholders with slightly more than 50 percent of GM’s 27.2 billion dollars in bond debt agreed to support the plan by the government-set deadline. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	5	917	Among the backers was a committee of large investors holding about 20 percent of GM’s outstanding bonds, The Times said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	6	1047	No official announcement of the vote tally has yet been made. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	7	1118	Under the plan, the bondholders would obtain the rights to buy an extra 15 percent of GM's stock at a low price. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	8	1231	They would also control 25 percent of the "new GM," after having supported the new company's creation in bankruptcy court. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	9	1363	Recalcitrant bondholders who opt for confrontation rather than cooperation "will get nothing or very little," an Obama administration official told reporters Thursday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	10	1540	Government-backed restructuring in bankruptcy court for GM, once the world's largest automaker, appeared all but certain ahead of a Monday deadline imposed by the Obama administration on the company to submit a viable restructuring plan or file for bankruptcy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	11	1810	It could take place as early as Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	0	58	Sri Lanka seeks help in dismantling Tigers' global network 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	1	193	Sri Lanka appealed Sunday for support in dismantling the Tamil Tigers' international support network after declaring victory over the rebels following the decades-long conflict. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	2	380	Foreign Minister Rohitha Bogollagama told a high-level security forum in Singapore that the global organisation of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) remained "largely intact." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	3	575	"Many of the operatives have clearly cultivated powerful, political lobbies in certain capitals with a view to resurrecting the LTTE," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	4	728	"It is important for the international community to take all measures to assist the government of Sri Lanka to track down the global network of the LTTE," he told an annual forum of defence and military officials organised by the London- based International Institute for Strategic Studies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	5	1028	Sri Lanka's military claimed complete victory over the separatist Tamil Tigers after wiping out the guerrillas' leadership nearly two weeks ago, but has been dogged by accusations that thousands of civilians were killed in the final weeks of the campaign. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	6	1293	The LTTE launched a campaign in 1972 to create a Tamil homeland in the Sinhalese-majority island. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	7	1391	Much of its funding came from Tamils overseas. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	8	1447	Bogollagama dismissed allegations that heavy weapons were used by the military in civilian areas as part of the "propaganda of genocide against the Tamil people." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	9	1619	"This was both fictional and well-fabricated, with ulterior and sinister motives in order to discredit the armed forces as well as to embarrass the government of Sri Lanka," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	10	1812	"Sri Lanka will no doubt enter the annals of history as a classic textbook example of a nation that successfully prevailed over the scourge of terrorism, whilst tenaciously upholding the cherished values of democracy and human rights that have been deeply engraved in the psyche of our people," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	11	2125	"The government is firmly committed to reaching a political settlement acceptable to all," the foreign minister said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	12	2252	Sri Lanka's handling of the LTTE "has sent a strong signal to the international community that terror can be defeated and terrorism can be eliminated," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	13	2423	Amnesty International called Saturday for an independent probe into the number of civilians killed following a report in London's Times newspaper citing confidential UN reports that said more than 20,000 civilians were killed by Sri Lankan army shelling. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	14	2687	Sri Lanka's Human Rights Minister Mahinda Samarasinghe has dismissed Amnesty's call and said the organisation was being "ridiculous to keep harping on things they cannot substantiate." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	0	58	Boxing: Berto retains WBC welterweight title 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	1	188	Haitian-born American Andre Berto retained his World Boxing Council welterweight title Saturday with a lopsided unanimous 12-round decision over Colombian Juan Urango. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	2	365	Two judges scored the bout 118-110 for the Florida-based Berto, while a third saw it 117-111. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	3	468	Berto remained unbeaten in 25 professional fights, with 19 wins inside the distance. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	4	562	Urango was frustrated by the nimble Berto, who kept his distance and scored to the head with the jab and with his right. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	5	692	Urango' best round was the fourth, when he landed a series of lefts to the head and body. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	6	791	But Berto largely avoided Urango's pressure, givig him little opportunity to get inside in the middle rounds while connecting himself with shots to Urango's head with both hands. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	7	979	After a lackluster ninth round drew jeers from the crowd, Berto stepped it up in the last three rounds. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	8	1092	Urango, who fell to 21-2-1 with 16 wins inside the distance, will now return to the super lightweight ranks, where he is still the International Boxing Federation title holder.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0390	1	89	Iran defuses bomb on board domestic flight: Fars agency 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	0	58	Taliban take war to Pakistan cities 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	1	170	Taliban rebels in Pakistan are taking their war to the cities, honing terror tactics to maximise civilian carnage after suffering heavy losses in a blistering military offensive, analysts say. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	2	372	Pakistan has been rocked by 14 bomb blasts that have killed more than 80 people in urban areas since it launched a determined air and ground assault against the Taliban in pockets of the northwest at the end of April. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	3	599	The military said on Saturday that troops had regained control of the main town of Mingora in Swat valley from the Taliban, in what is being touted as a significant milestone in the month-long ongoing offensive. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	4	820	But the rebels, who Washington fears threaten Pakistan's very existence, are striking back in cities like the regional capital Peshawar, about 200 kilometres (125 miles) from Mingora and previously shielded from major attacks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	5	1056	"They are taking this war to the cities, hoping to build up enough pressure on the government to halt the military activity," security analyst Hasan Askari told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	6	1231	"The Taliban challenge now threatens routine life and commercial activity in cities... allied extremist groups are facilitating their agenda," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	7	1393	Attackers are becoming increasingly sophisticated, analysts say, executing commando-style assaults armed with suicide vests, vehicle bombs, guns, grenades and rockets. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	8	1570	Over the last two weeks in Peshawar, bombs have exploded outside a cinema, near crowded electronics shops, at a police checkpoint and even alongside a bus full of children with special needs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	9	1771	And in Lahore, Pakistan's entertainment capital, a bomb, gun and grenade assault killed 24 people and partially damaged the provincial headquarters of the country's premier spy agency on Wednesday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	10	1978	It was the third spectacular assault in and around the eastern city -- hundreds of miles from the offensive in the northwest -- in as many months. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	11	2134	The Tehreek-e-Taliban (TTP) militant group claimed responsibility, telling people in a statement they should get out of the cities because there will be more violence to come. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	12	2319	Newspaper columnist Shafqat Mehmood said the Taliban, who want to enforce sharia law, are becoming more and more desperate in the face of the military onslaught in the northwest, which the army says has claimed 1,200 rebels. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	13	2553	"Militants are under pressure and will employ any tactic to cause maximum damage. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	14	2635	Urban terrorism is one of those tactics," said Mehmood. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	15	2700	While the government could do more to protect key targets, he said, underfunded and overstretched security forces can only do so much. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	16	2844	"It is difficult to patrol markets and streets," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	17	2912	"Our province is facing a war-like situation," the police chief of North West Frontier Province, Malik Naved Khan, told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	18	3046	"We have 9,000 police. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	19	3069	In a big city like Peshawar, this is not enough to deal with situations like the one we're facing," said Khan. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	20	3189	Northwest expert Rahimullah Yusufzai said the Taliban were increasingly focused on civilian targets as widespread public opinion turns -- for the first time -- in favour of Pakistan's military operation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	21	3402	The offensive already has the firm backing of Washington, which says Al-Qaeda and Taliban have carved out safe havens in the northwestern areas bordering Afghanistan to plot terror attacks on the West. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	22	3613	"The Taliban have jacked up attacks targeting civilians as they have failed to target security forces," Yusufzai said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	23	3741	Echoing Hasan Askari, he added the Taliban will likely have willing allies from a catalogue of banned radical groups that traditionally have battled India in Kashmir. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	24	3917	These include Lashkar-i-Jhangvi, Yusufzai said, an extremist element linked to Al-Qaeda, and Lashkar-e-Taiba, accused of carrying out the Mumbai attacks last year that left 166 dead. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	25	4109	"These extremist outfits and TTP (Tehreek-e-Taliban) have a relationship that runs in their blood. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	26	4208	They are natural allies who lived and fought together." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	27	4273	Alarmingly, the government in Islamabad had no particular strategy to prevent attacks on cities, Yusufzai said, warning he did not see an end to the urban bloodshed any time soon. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	28	4462	"I don't think the situation can be brought under control quickly because it has roots in (the tribal areas of) Waziristan and Bajaur, and what is happening in those two regions is linked to the Taliban in Afghanistan," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	0	58	Aung San Suu Kyi 'covered up' truth: Myanmar junta 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	1	185	Opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi "covered up" the truth by failing to report an American man in her home, a senior Myanmar official said Sunday, warning foreigners not to interfere in the case. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	2	390	"It is no doubt that Daw Aung San Suu Kyi has committed a cover-up of the truth by her failure to report an illegal immigrant to the authorities concerned," Major General Aye Myint, Myanmar's deputy defence minister, told a security forum in Singapore. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	3	652	"Thus there was no option but to open legal proceedings in accordance with the law," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	4	755	"She permitted him to stay.... 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	5	786	She communicated, provided him food and shelter," Aye Myint said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	6	861	Aung San Suu Kyi, a Nobel peace laureate, is facing up to five years' detention on charges relating to the surprise visit of an eccentric American to her lakeside prison home in early May. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	7	1059	In his speech to regional security officials and experts, the general said the case against Aung San Suu Kyi was an internal matter for Myanmar to resolve without foreign intervention. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	8	1253	"Countries should refrain from interfering in the internal affairs of Myanmar that will affect peace and security of the region," sid Aye Myint. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	9	1407	"Solving one's internal affairs through its legal system with legal proceedings in accordance with law does not amount to the threat of peace or breach of security of the region," he said in an apparent reaction to criticism of the charges against Aung San Suu Kyi from other forum participants. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	10	1712	Ann Taylor, Britain's minister for international defence and security, said at the meeting earlier Sunday that Aung San Suu Kyi should be released. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	11	1869	"The continued imprisonment of Aung San Suu Kyi by the Burmese regime is a reminder that we cannot take for granted the institution of democracy," she said, referring to Myanmar by its former name. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	12	2076	"The people of Burma have suffered for nearly half a century of conflict and isolation, but Aung San Suu Kyi is not alone," Taylor said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	13	2222	"People all around the world are standing with her and the Burmese people and we say to the generals: Now is the time for transition to democracy starting with the release of Aung San Suu Kyi." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0393	0	58	3 Palestinian police and 1 Hamas militant killed in clash: police 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0393	1	208	Three Palestinian police officers and one Hamas militant were killed in an exchange of gunfire on Sunday in the northern West Bank town of Qalqilya, Palestinian police said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0393	2	391	The policemen were killed while they were attempting to arrest Mohammad Yassine, a member of the Ezzedine al-Qassam Brigades, Hamas's military wing, who had barricaded himself in his home. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0393	3	589	Two other police officers were killed in the exchange of gunfire. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0393	4	664	A curfew was imposed on the town following the incident, said the police. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0393	5	747	Hamas, a bitter rival of the Fatah movement of Palestinian Authority president Mahmoud Abbas, violently ousted Fatah from the Gaza Strip in June 2007, effectively limiting Abbas's rule to the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	0	58	Blogging guru chips away at Great Firewall of China 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	1	186	How would you react if one million of your customers were suddenly stopped from coming into your shop? 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	2	289	Matt Mullenweg just shrugged. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	3	328	The 25-year-old American is the founder of Wordpress, software that allows computer users worldwide to easily create their own websites, or blogs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	4	484	The simplicity of Wordpress has made it one of the world's top blogging platforms six years after it was set up, its adherents ranging from knitting fanatics (jessinohio.wordpress.com) to CNN's resident doctor Sanjay Gupta (pagingdrgupta.blogs.cnn.com/site). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	5	752	But in 2006, as the site was growing from strength to strength, Chinese authorities suddenly blocked it. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	6	866	Overnight, one million Chinese visitors to the various blogs disappeared, accounting for about a quarter of all traffic to the site. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	7	1008	"I wish there was a better story, but really it just went away one day and we didn't know what to do about it," Mullenweg told AFP, during a visit to Hong Kong to speak to some of his bloggers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	8	1211	After some discussions, Mullenweg realised the site would be allowed back online if he agreed to block certain words or topics and give up information to the Chinese communist government about users. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	9	1420	"I started thinking about the DNA of the company," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	10	1480	"That sort of company is not one I would wake up every day and feel passionate about working in." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	11	1587	The site remains blocked, although Mullenweg, unable to suppress a giggle, points out that the official Chinese line insists it is freely available. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	12	1745	His decision not to pander to China contrasts sharply with other companies that have agreed to the country's extensive Internet controls -- often dubbed the Great Firewall of China -- in the hope of gaining access to what is now the world's biggest online market. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	13	2018	Yahoo! 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	14	2025	faced fierce criticism when it helped Chinese authorities identify a journalist who had passed on a sensitive Communist Party message to foreign websites. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	15	2180	The journalist, Shi Tao, was subsequently jailed in 2005. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	16	2247	"I imagine that weighs very heavily on both the leadership of that company and also the morale of an entire organisation," said Mullenweg, who is based in San Francisco and has done several recent deals with Yahoo!. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	17	2472	Despite the ban, Chinese bloggers still use Wordpress technology in huge numbers, downloading its free access software and pasting their blogs through another server to avoid the censors. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	18	2669	That's just the kind of technology-inspired rebellion that appeals to Mullenweg, who has also refused to submit to similar government demands in Turkey, and whose instinct is to make things freely-available. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	19	2886	He is considering putting all the firm's expenses online, so everyone at Automattic, Wordpress's parent company, can access them. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	20	3016	And his camera, which goes everywhere with him, carries a global positioning system, so he records the exact location of all his pictures. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	21	3164	This openness is reflected in Wordpress's approach -- the blogging software is open source, so it can be downloaded and tinkered with as users see fit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	22	3325	As a result of its accessibility and it simplicity, it now has more than 15 million bloggers using its technology, according to statistics on the site. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	23	3486	While setting up a blog is free, the site makes money by advertising or charging for extras, such as enhanced statistics packages or better promotion of a particular blog. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	24	3667	Mullenweg has become the darling of the Internet world, regularly featuring on lists of the "most powerful people in cyberspace" and accepting invitations to talk about how the web is changing the world. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	25	3880	The company, which still has fewer than 100 employees, remains privately held and so does not have to reveal earnings, and though reports have said Mullenweg turned down an offer of 200 million dollars in 2007 for a stake in the firm, money one of the few subjects he is reluctant to discuss. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	26	4182	"We are doing well, capital is not a limiting factor for us," said Mullenweg, dressed in battered trainers and jeans after addressing a group of business leaders. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	27	4354	"I like that we always get the question how do you make money, because it means that we are not crassly over-commercialising," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	28	4499	His passion for simplicity was learned as teenage volunteer at the Houston Area League of PC Users, in the US city where he grew up. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	29	4632	His job was fixing computers every Saturday for mainly elderly PC users. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	30	4714	"You saw all the cliches -- CD-ROMS being used as a cup holder, but they were just trying to connect with (the technology). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	31	4838	It was inspiring," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	32	4875	"You really develop an appreciation (for simplicity) and developing software is the same. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	33	4974	"People don't want to use Wordpress (for its own sake), they want to talk to their audience, share photos of their family and (Wordpress) is either a way for them to do that or it is not."
