AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	0	58	Ethiopia: lifting the mystery on rock churches 'built by angels' 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	1	208	The ancient mystery shrouding Lalibela, Ethiopia's revered medieval rock-hewn churches, could be lifted by a group of French researchers given the go-ahead for the first comprehensive study of this world heritage site legend says was "built by angels". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	2	470	The team will have full access to the network of 10 Orthodox chapels chiseled out of volcanic rock -- some standing 15 metres (42 feet) high -- in the mountainous heart of Ethiopia. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	3	661	Local lore holds they were built in less than 25 years by their namesake, the 13th-century King Lalibela, with the help of angels after God ordered him to erect a "New Jerusalem". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	4	850	The monolithic structures are located 500 kilometres (300 miles) north of the capital Addis Ababa. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	5	949	Long a holy pilgrimage site in a land proud of its Christian Orthodox heritage, they are also a travel draw in a poverty-stricken country hoping to boost tourism. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	6	1121	The multidisciplinary team of historians, archaeologists, topographers and a specialist in liturgy will spend several weeks probing the subterranean complex to try to identify its origins. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	7	1319	Historian Marie Laure Derat, with the French Centre for Ethiopian Studies (CFEE), said "there are several theories". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	8	1436	In one, "an Egyptian patriarch was believed to be the source of these structures, another says the 13th-century King Lalibela built the site from scratch." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	9	1601	"During the day the king would work with Ethiopian artisans and at night he would 'be helped by angels'. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	10	1706	Some even cite a key role by the Knights Templar," she said, referring to one of the key Western Christian military orders of the Middle Ages. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	11	1858	Though earlier studies have been carried out, they were generally by lone researchers with restricted access who studied mainly church interiors . 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	12	2014	Derat said the heretofore reluctant Orthodox church gave the French team carte blanche to probe "the entire site, not just the churches, to understand how the periods overlap and to read history in this open book that is Lalibela". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	13	2255	Funded by the French government and Ethiopian Airlines, the team is already certain the chapels were not built in one go. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	14	2386	Research chief Francois Xavier Fauvelle said three distinct periods have been identified in the maze of deep tunnels, passageways and chapels, some of which resemble ancient Greek temples. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	15	2584	"There was originally a basalt dome under which we found evidence of cave dwellers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	16	2668	Then there was the construction of a fortress with trenches, a perimetre wall and underground tunnels," he said pointing to rocks he said where once part of the defence wall. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	17	2852	"The third period was established thanks to an enormous mound of earth about 20 metres high that came from the excavation of the church of Gabriel Ruphael," he said, referring to the chapel some believe was once King Lalibela's residence. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	18	3100	"The Ruphael Gabriel church was probably part of the fortress and was turned into a church: the facade was extended, windows opened and a chapel dug out," said Fauvelle. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	19	3279	UNESCO added Lalibela to its world heritage list in 1978, a boon for tourism efforts in this country of 85 million where poverty is rampant and agriculture accounts for nearly half the economy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	20	3473	Visitors can already join organized tours of the site. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	21	3537	But the bid to shed light on its origins has not shaken the Orthodox clergy and faithful here, who contend that Lalibela arose with divine intervention. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	22	3699	"It is God through his angels who made these churches," said Alebachew Reta, spokesman for the Lalibela clergy who insisted "the 10 churches were created in just 24 years." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	23	3881	"You can observe that even one would be difficult to build in that space of time. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	24	3963	So for us it is God's work," said Reta. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	25	4003	"For the one who created mankind, building these churches was not difficult." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	0	58	Jewish settlers say they remain in West Bank on God's orders 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	1	208	The world outcry over Israeli settlements in the West Bank is absurd since God gave this land to the Jews, says Rabbi Yaakov Savir. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	2	340	The Arabs, he says, should make their home elsewhere. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	3	403	"This territory is Jewish territory," says Savir, a settler who runs a religious school in the Havat Gilad outpost which consists of little more than a few tin huts and weather-worn trailers, some horses and chickens and several car wrecks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	4	653	"This is our home," he says, making a sweeping gesture towards the Jewish settlements that dominate nearby hilltops to show he means the entire West Bank, which Israel captured from Jordan in the 1967 Six-Day-War. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	5	876	Havat Gilad, which 20 families call home, is a wildcat outpost, meaning that unlike full-scale settlements, it is not authorised by the Israeli government. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	6	1041	The international community considers all settlements illegal, and the issue is one of the thorniest in peace efforts with the Palestinians. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	7	1191	With US pressure mounting, Israel could soon make good on its years-old pledge to tear down a couple of dozen outposts. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	8	1320	In Havat Gilad's case, it wouldn't be the first time. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	9	1383	Built by Moshe Zar, a former member of a Jewish underground movement that planted bombs in the cars of Arab mayors, the outpost was torn down by the Israeli authorities barely hours after a group of teenagers pitched the first tents in 2002. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	10	1625	Rebuilding started the next day. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	11	1667	Savir is outraged the government of right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu would even consider bulldozing Jewish homes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	12	1802	"Jewish people live here by Biblical right," he claims, standing in the trailer that houses the religious school, surrounded by students who sport the look favoured by ideologically motivated religious settlers -- long locks, knitted skullcap, loose clothing and sandals. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	13	2083	Savir insists he has nothing against Arabs -- he won't speak of Palestinians other than to say there is no such people. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	14	2212	"If Arabs want to stay, we won't kill them, we won't expel them. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	15	2286	"They are the ones who want to kill us, who don't want us to live in our home," he says. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	16	2384	"Arabs," he adds "should find another place to live." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	17	2447	The vast majority of the 280,000 Jews who live in the 120 West Bank settlements which Israel considers legal, have moved to the area for economic reasons. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	18	2602	But the hardliners who share Savir's views that Jewish people have a God-given right to the land are extremely vocal and at times violent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	19	2750	Rabbi Savir is convinced the residents of Havat Gilad, like others in similar outposts, "will certainly fight for every millimeter. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	20	2882	No one will leave his home." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	21	2920	Israel agreed in 2003 to freeze all settlement activity and raze wildcat outposts but has not followed through on those commitments. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	22	3062	Outposts, typically located a few hundred metres (yards) from government- authorised settlements, include anything from a few shacks to communities of several dozen semi-permanent homes connected to the electricity and water grids. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	23	3303	Many of the 100 or so outposts were built on West Bank hills by militant teenagers, known as "hilltop youths," with the aim of planting the seeds of new full-fledged settlements. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	24	3491	A 2005 government-commissioned report said that in some cases officials authorised seizure of private Palestinian land to create outposts, and facilitated their connection to the water and power mains. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	25	3702	Palestinians see the outposts as part of a land grab and a scheme to further consolidate Israel's control over the West Bank, which is home to 2.4 million Palestinians. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	26	3880	Faced with mounting pressure from within his right-wing coalition on the one hand and the United States on the other, Netanyahu has vowed to continue building in existing settlement blocs while indicating he will dismantle wildcat outposts. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	27	4130	But he has failed to placate either side. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	28	4181	The premier has faced fierce criticism from the right for his willingness to tear down Jewish homes, and some blunt talk from Washington over settlement expansion. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	29	4354	US President Barack Obama told Netanyahu during May 18 White House talks he wants a complete freeze of settlement activity. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	30	4487	"Not some settlements, not outposts, not natural growth exceptions," Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said, explaining the demand. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	31	4629	Israeli police did tear down Maoz Esther, north of the West Bank political capital of Ramallah, on May 21, but the move was dismissed by Israeli media as a meaningless token gesture. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	32	4812	The outpost consisted of just seven tin and plywood shacks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	33	4881	One week after the demolition, one house had already been rebuilt and another was being constructed without any hindrance from the authorities. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	34	5034	"We must settle here, God has ordered us to live on this land," says Daniel Landesberg, 20, as he and a group of teenagers spread out cement being poured out of a large concrete mixer truck to form the base of a new house. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	35	5266	Landesberg is a firm believer in the "doubling" tactic adopted by hardline settlers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	36	5360	"They tore down seven homes, we will build 14," he says, smiling. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	37	5435	And if the 14 are razed? 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	38	5460	"We'll build twice that many."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	0	58	Struggling GM thrives in China 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	1	164	GM's overall future may look grim, but half a world away from Detroit in Shanghai, business has never been better. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	2	288	The US auto giant is beating sales records in China and may soon be exporting Chinese-made cars to the United States. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	3	415	"I don't think it makes much difference to us. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	4	462	Obviously we'd prefer to have this restructuring done outside the courts," Kevin Wale, GM China's president and managing director, told AFP in a recent interview. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	5	634	"We operate as independent joint ventures here in China so we would continue pretty much as we are today." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	6	750	While GM pares back at home, it may add a plant in China to meet its goal of doubling annual sales to two million within five years with products developed for "the most important growth market in the world", Wale said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	7	979	That extra capacity could also help produce GM cars which for the first time would be exported from China to the United States, under a proposal the automaker has reportedly submitted to US lawmakers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	8	1189	GM has proposed shipping 17,335 Chinese-made cars to the US in 2011 and increasing that to 51,546 by 2014 -- representing 1.6 percent of its forecast 3.1 million cars five years from now, the Automotive News reported. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	9	1416	China led the world in auto sales in April, and GM China's joint ventures led the pack, with sales rising 29.9 percent on year to 151,084 vehicles, driven by demand for Buicks and small Wuling "bread vans" that cost less than 5,000 dollars. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	10	1666	"It's definitely one of the market leaders here -- in drastic contrast to their performance in the US," said Shen Jun, an auto analyst at Roland Berger. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	11	1828	GM's first Shanghai sales office opened in 1929, boasting: "Buick owners are mostly the leading men in China." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	12	1948	Pu Yi, the last emperor, revolutionary leader Sun Yat-sen and premier Zhou Enlai all owned Buicks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	13	2056	But that history is barely known, allowing GM to recast Buick as a car for China's young and fast-growing middle class. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	14	2185	"Volkswagen has good prices and good quality, but their cars look very average, not unique," said Li Pengxiang, a 29-year-old telecoms project manager, referring to China's number two carmaker. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	15	2388	"These new (GM) models look fresh and suit young people." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	16	2455	GM has earned a reputation for savvy marketing with moves like enlisting "Prison Break" star Wentworth Miller -- a top celebrity in China despite the show never airing here legally -- to star in its latest campaign, Shen said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	17	2691	"They think they are doing much better than the parent company in the US," he said, saying GM's success in China boils down to smart decisions, good timing and luck that has put it far ahead of US rivals Ford and Chrysler. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	18	2923	GM teamed with China's largest automaker Shanghai Automotive Industry Group or SAIC, in 1997 -- foreign carmakers here need a local joint venture partner -- after SAIC rejected Toyota and before Ford could sign a deal, Shen said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	19	3162	Tension among joint venture partners is common, but GM and SAIC are known to have unrivalled chemistry, according to Zhu Junyi, an auto analyst at the Shanghai Information Centre. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	20	3351	GM spends heavily on research and development while delegating key responsibilities to its partner, he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	21	3469	"German and Japanese investors are more reluctant to give away any leadership role," Zhu said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	22	3564	"GM has done a better job with localisation." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	23	3619	GM's growing sales are impressive but competitors are growing faster -- Hyundai shot up 74 percent on year last month while Nissan sales grew 55 percent, Shen said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	24	3793	Even as the Chinese market's growth slows -- to eight percent in 2008 after years of double digit growth -- more players are piling in. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	25	3938	"The Japanese automakers are steamrolling China's auto market," said Eric Xu, head of Timer-Auto Consulting in Shanghai. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	0	58	GM's collapse will mark end of a blue collar dynasty 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	1	195	The expected collapse of General Motors will mark the death of a blue collar dynasty which bestowed upon generations of Americans the security of a job for life and a ticket to the middle class. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	2	399	"GM represented the good life," said Gary Chaison, a professor of labor relations at Clark University. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	3	511	"There was a social contract: you worked hard and the company would reward you with job security and good pay," Chaison told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	4	641	"And this was something you could pass on (to your kids.) 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	5	699	It was an inheritance." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	6	732	In towns and cities scattered across the midwest, GM's sprawling plants and the businesses which cropped up to service them brought prosperity and stability. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	7	899	The United Auto Workers union won wages high enough to allow factory workers to own a home, a cottage, a boat, to take summer vacations in cars they bought with employee discounts. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	8	1089	Their health insurance was paid for. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	9	1126	Pensions would offer guaranteed income in retirement. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	10	1180	They worked for the biggest corporation in the world. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	11	1243	That dream began to slip away in the 1980s, when GM began shutting down plants and shipping production to Mexico and Asia. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	12	1375	Once bustling company towns like Flint, Michigan -- memorialized in Michael Moore's documentary "Roger &amp; Me" -- emptied and died. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	13	1509	Abandoned houses and darkened storefronts transformed the once rich region into the Rust Belt. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	14	1613	GM employed 440,000 hourly workers in the United States in 1981. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	15	1687	By 2000, that had dropped to 133,000. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	16	1725	In the next eight years it would fall to 62,000. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	17	1783	The latest restructuring plan calls for the unionized workforce to shrink to 38,000 by 2011: less than a tenth of what it was two decades earlier. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	18	1939	But even through the downsizing and plant closures of the 1980s and 1990s, the workers who remained at General Motors were able to hang onto their high wages and benefits. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	19	2120	That ended in the latest round of restructuring, which began in 2005 and ended with the union agreeing to slash benefits, cut wages in half for new workers, and even give up the right to strike until 2015. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	20	2335	"It could have been worse," said Doug Bowman, the president of UAW Local 594 in Pontiac, Michigan. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	21	2443	Bowman has worked for GM for 30 years and has watched employment at his complex shrink from 14,000 in the late 1970s to 1,000 today. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	22	2585	He's anxiously awaiting news about whether his truck plant will be among 14 GM plants slated for closure. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	23	2691	But he's resigned himself to the massive concessions the union has made in recent years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	24	2789	"The one thing I regret is that we couldn't protect the retirees," he told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	25	2878	"We have no choice," said Jim Hall, another UAW official from Pontiac. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	26	2958	"We have to vote for the concessions to help the company survive." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	27	3034	But Hall hasn't given up hope. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	28	3065	If GM manages to emerge from bankruptcy protection, which it is expected to seek in the coming days, Hall thinks some of jobs, and some of those benefits, might come back. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	29	3246	GM, which only months ago lost the title of the world's biggest automaker to Toyota after holding it for 77 years, had made huge steps in recent years to revitalize its products and slash its bloated structural costs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	30	3473	But the restructuring cost billions and the debt-laden automaker was unable to survive the collapse of auto sales last fall amid a credit crunch and deepening recession. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	31	3652	GM racked up nearly 88 billion dollars in losses from 2005 through the first quarter of 2009, and has only managed to keep its operations afloat in recent months with 19.4 billion dollars in loans from the US Treasury. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	32	3880	The hope is that, like Chrysler, GM will emerge from bankruptcy in a matter of weeks as a leaner, meaner company able to get back to the business of making cars and trucks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	33	4062	But while the union is likely to hold a large stake in the new General Motors, its power to shape the American social landscape through sheer numbers is gone. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	34	4230	"Certainly an era has ended," said Harley Shaiken, a labor expert from the University of California - Berkeley. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	35	4351	"We're in uncharted waters." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	0	58	Once the world's biggest corporation, GM faces collapse 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	1	198	Once the biggest corporation in the world, steady growth overseas was unable to rescue General Motors from spiralling losses in the United States. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	2	354	Founded in 1908, GM sold more vehicles than any other automaker from 1931 until 2008, when it was overtaken by Japan's Toyota. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	3	490	The largest of the Detroit Three automakers, GM has seen its US market share fall from a peak of 54 percent in the 1954 to just 22 percent in 2008. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	4	647	It nonetheless sold a whopping 8.35 million vehicles in 2008 despite a collapse in global auto sales amid a credit crunch and widening economic downturn. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	5	810	GM last made a profit in 2004, earning 2.8 billion dollars, and has been operating under ever-deepening restructuring plans ever since. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	6	946	It lost nearly 88 billion dollars from 2005 through the first quarter of 2009. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	7	1034	Global employment levels reached more than 850,000 in 1978, of which more than 600,000 were in the United States, making GM the nation's largest private employer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	8	1206	By 2005 it had already shrunk to 335,000 people and further cuts this year will bring it below 200,000 worldwide. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	9	1329	GM's unionized workforce has taken the most dramatic hit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	10	1387	GM employed 440,000 hourly workers in the United States in 1981. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	11	1461	By 2000, that had dropped to 133,000 and the automaker ended 2008 with just 62,000. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	12	1554	The latest restructuring plan calls for the unionized workforce to shrink to 38,000 by 2011: less than a tenth of what it was two decades earlier. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	13	1710	Once studied in business schools for the success of its brands, which operated as separate divisions aimed to satisfy different segments of the market, GM is shedding most of its marks -- including Sweden's Saab, Hummer, Pontiac and Saturn. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	14	1951	It will concentrate on Cadillac, Buick, Chevrolet and GMC. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	15	2019	The latest restructuring plan will shrink GM's US dealer network by 40 percent and will cut its US plants from 47 to 31. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	0	58	Troubled road which led to GM's breakdown 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	1	184	Here are the principal events marking GM's troubled path over the past 18 months, with the once mighty automaker expected to file for bankruptcy soon. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	2	344	JANUARY 2008 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	3	366	-- Toyota comes close to overtaking GM as the world's biggest automaker, a title GM has held since 1931. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	4	471	GM sells 9.369 million vehicles in 2007 while the Japanese automaker sold 9.366 million. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	5	569	FEBRUARY 2008 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	6	592	-- GM posts a 38.7 billion dollar annual loss for 2007 and announces plans to eliminate the jobs of 74,000 unionized workers in the United States. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	7	748	MARCH 2008 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	8	768	-- A two-month long strike begins at key supplier American Axle. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	9	833	GM is forced to shut many of its plants and takes a 1.8 billion dollar hit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	10	918	APRIL 2008 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	11	938	-- GM slashes production of trucks and sport utility vehicles by 140,000 units in the wake of poor sales. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	12	1053	JULY 2008 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	13	1072	-- GM announces plans to slash its white collar workforce by 20 percent, double truck production cuts to 300,000 units and bolster its liquidity by 15 billion dollars through internal operating actions, asset sales and the capital markets. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	14	1321	AUGUST 2008 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	15	1342	-- GM reports a second quarter loss of 15.5 billion dollars. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	16	1412	SEPTEMBER 2008 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	17	1436	-- GM marks its 100th anniversary. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	18	1480	OCTOBER 2008 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	19	1502	-- Merger talks between GM and Chrysler heat up as US sales collapse amid a deepening recession. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	20	1608	NOVEMBER 2008 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	21	1631	-- GM announces October sales fell 45 percent amid the US auto industry's worst performance in the post World War II era. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	22	1762	-- GM, Chrysler and Ford executives head to Washington to request billions in emergency loans. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	23	1866	-- Merger talks with Chrysler are dropped. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	24	1918	DECEMBER 2008 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	25	1941	-- GM announces plans to cut another 31,000 jobs by 2012 and idles a third of its US factories. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	26	2046	-- The White House offers GM and Chrysler 13.3 billion dollars in emergency loans. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	27	2138	-- The Canadian government offers 3.3 billion US dollars in aid to GM and Chrysler. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	28	2231	JANUARY 2009 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	29	2253	-- Toyota claims the crown of world's biggest automaker after selling 8.97 million vehicles in 2008. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	30	2354	GM's global sales have fallen to 8.35 million vehicles. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	31	2419	-- Industry data shows 2008 US auto sales were down 18 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	32	2483	GM's sales fell 23 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	33	2520	FEBRUARY 2009 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	34	2543	-- GM and Chrysler present restructuring plans to the US Treasury. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	35	2610	GM asks for another 16.6 billion in loans and says it will cut 47,000 jobs worldwide this year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	36	2706	That will bring its global workforce down to 200,000 from 335,000 in 2005. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	37	2790	-- GM asks Canada to boost its loans to six billion dollars. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	38	2860	-- GM reports a 31 billion dollar loss for 2008, bringing its cumulative losses since 2005 to 86 billion dollars. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	39	2983	-- GM washes its hands of Saab after the Swedish government refuses to bail out the troubled unit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	40	3082	Saab seeks legal restructuring protection to avoid bankruptcy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	41	3154	MARCH 2009 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	42	3174	-- GM's auditors express "substantial doubt" about its ability to stay afloat in the automaker's annual report. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	43	3295	-- Longtime chief executive officer Rick Wagoner resigns at the request of the White House, which tells the automaker to come up with a better viability plan. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	44	3463	APRIL 2009 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	45	3483	-- GM deepens its restructuring plan to cut more jobs, eliminate Pontiac and Saturn, shrink its dealer network by 42 percent by 2010. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	46	3626	-- Attempts to swap 27 billion dollars in debt for a 10 percent stake in common shares. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	47	3723	-- Idles 13 plants for "multiple weeks." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	48	3773	-- Enters talks to sell a major stake in Opel. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	49	3829	MAY 2009 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	50	3847	-- Posts a first quarter loss of 5.9 billion dollars as quarterly production is slashed by 40 percent, or 903,000 units. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	51	3977	-- Reaches cost-cutting deals with its US and Canadian unions. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	52	4049	-- Receives another four billion in US government loans, bringing total to 19.4 billion. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	0	58	Collapse of once mighty GM was decades in the making 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	1	185	The downfall of General Motors comes after decades of mistakes and missteps chipped away at the reputation and market share of the once mighty automaker and buried the Detroit giant in debt. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	2	385	"It'll have a huge impact in the United States because it's more than just a corporation -- it's an icon," said Gary Chaison, a professor of labor relations at Clark University. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	3	572	"It represented manufacturing supremacy and good jobs for American workers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	4	648	That's gone." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	5	671	GM, which only months ago lost the title of the world's biggest automaker to Toyota after holding it for 77 years, had made huge steps in recent years to revitalize its products and slash its bloated structural costs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	6	898	But the restructuring cost billions and the debt-laden automaker has fought hard to survive the collapse of auto sales last fall amid a credit crunch and deepening recession. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	7	1082	GM racked up nearly 88 billion dollars in losses from 2005 through the first quarter of 2009. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	8	1185	It managed to keep its operations afloat in recent months with 19.4 billion dollars in loans from the US Treasury but is now expected to seek bankruptcy protection in the coming days. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	9	1378	"GM's problems go back at least three decades," said Terrence Guay, a professor at Penn State's business school. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	10	1500	"The company became complacent in terms of products and customers, assuming that American car-buyers would choose GM vehicles," he told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	11	1650	"They didn't take the Japanese threat seriously, and consequently steadily lost market share to Toyota, Honda, Nissan, and other imports." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	12	1798	GM was a giant in its chrome-detailed heyday, employing more than 600,000 people worldwide and 464,000 in the United States back in 1962 when it sold more than half the cars in America. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	13	1993	Founded in 1908, GM grew to be the largest private US employer, the world's biggest company, had revenues higher than the gross domestic product of most nations, and currently operates in 140 countries. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	14	2205	After transforming its plants to make planes, tanks and munitions during World War II, GM expanded far beyond cars in the decades to follow, building everything from trains and rockets to home air conditioners. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	15	2425	GM also helped expand the American middle class with the standard-setting high wages and solid benefit packages won by hundreds of thousands of unionized auto workers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	16	2602	The phrase "what's good for GM is good for the country" became commonplace. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	17	2687	"Between 1921 and 1980 they never lost money," said Sean McAlinden, chief economist at Michigan's Center for Automotive Research. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	18	2826	"The target was a 20 percent return on capital every year no matter what. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	19	2900	And they did it." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	20	2927	But GM and its Detroit neighbors, Ford and Chrysler, let their quality slip and fumbled the shift to smaller, more fuel efficient vehicles in the wake of the oil crises of the 1970s. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	21	3119	"The baby boom generation has never forgiven them for the defects of the 1970s and 80s," McAlinden told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	22	3237	"They will go to their graves without buying a GM vehicle." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	23	3306	Japanese automakers Toyota and Honda steadily gained market share first with the low cost of their vehicles and then with their reputation for higher quality. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	24	3474	Plant closures became a part of the American motif and GM shed most of its subsidiaries. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	25	3572	The Detroit Three were able to revive their fortunes in the 1990s with the development of sport utility vehicles and the rising popularity of trucks, but the profits were short-lived. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	26	3765	Japanese automakers responded to Detroit's hulking truck-based suvs with smaller, more efficient car-based crossovers suvs and once again GM was slow to follow suit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	27	3940	When fuel prices began to rise and consumers shifted away from gasoline guzzles, GM's sales -- and profits -- crashed. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	28	4068	The latest round of plant closures and layoffs began in November 2005. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	29	4148	Since then, GM's US workforce has been slashed by nearly half from 160,000 at the end of 2004 to 83,315 at the end of April. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	30	4282	The real problem, analysts say, is that GM waited too long to address the ballooning "legacy costs" associated with supporting generations of retirees with a US market share that had slipped to 26 percent by 2005. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	31	4505	GM's costs for each vehicle built were about 2,000 to 2,500 dollars higher than the US plants of its Asian rivals. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	32	4629	GM was able to reach a historic deal with the United Auto Workers union to slash labor costs in 2007, but only after spending 103 billion dollars to fund pensions and retiree health care from 1993 through 2007. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	33	4849	And though GM has managed to dramatically improve its product quality and offerings in recent years, it was too little too late. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	0	58	Can GM succeed as 'Government Motors'? 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	1	174	General Motors, readying a massive bankruptcy filing backed by billions in public funds, faces a complex set of challenges as a virtually nationalized "Government Motors," analysts say. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	2	369	With the US government expected to hold as much as 72.5 percent of the new firm that would emerge from bankruptcy, analysts say a big question is whether GM can concentrate on the difficult auto marketplace. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	3	586	"The tricky part is to leave day-to-day management to the executives of the company," said Jeremy Anwyl, chief executive at auto research firm Edmunds.com. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	4	751	For the government, he said, "the temptation is to influence product decisions based on political considerations instead of market considerations, and that's always a danger." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	5	936	Anwyl said it is too soon to tell how the matter will be handled by the administration of President Barack Obama, which has pledged to get out of the business as soon as GM gets back on its feet. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	6	1141	David Cole, chairman of the Michigan-based Center for Automotive Research, said the government officials "are smart, dedicated people, but they can't learn the key issues of this industry in a short time." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	7	1356	Cole said the government can succeed if it focuses on the goal of restoring profitability, getting taxpayer money repaid and then getting out of GM. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	8	1514	"If the government forces a company to go out of step with the reality of the marketplace, that's a problem," Cole said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	9	1644	"If you force the industry to build products they can't sell profitably, that's a problem." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	10	1745	Cole said it was "almost unavoidable that the government will try to superimpose other agendas" on the carmaker. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	11	1867	Cole and Anwyl said it would be a mistake for the government to use its role as the financial backer of GM or Chrysler to push the firms into building certain types of cars to meet environmental or other goals because consumer demands can change quickly. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	12	2131	Anwyl said that with the current level of fuel prices, demand for small, fuel- efficient cars is decreasing. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	13	2240	He added the Obama administration's effort to further boost fuel efficiency may hurt efforts to help Detroit automakers become profitable again. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	14	2394	Peter Cohan, a management consultant and faculty member at Babson College, said GM must keep a focus on "developing a line of products that can compete with Toyota, Nissan and the rest of the world." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	15	2603	"I hope the government doesn't push GM to make hybrids just for the sake of doing it but because it will be profitable strategy ... 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	16	2735	They need to design and build a vehicle that will last longer than a Toyota with lower maintenance costs." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	17	2851	Although some GM critics blame existing management for its woes, Anwyl said the carmaker's biggest problems stemmed from decisions made years or even decades earlier. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	18	3027	"These festered over the years and GM never really confronted them," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	19	3114	The US government is expected to invest an additional 30 billion dollars to help GM on top of its 20 billion dollars in loans, with most of the funds being converted to the equity stake of as much as 72.5 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	20	3337	The US stake could be reduced by a share given to the governments of Canada and Ontario province, expected to pitch in with around nine billion dollars. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	21	3499	John Pottow, a law professor and bankruptcy specialist at the University of Michigan, said the proposed ownership structure raises a lot of hackles. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	22	3657	"Everyone is terrified of government mandates as opposed to market forces," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	23	3742	"But I take it as face value the government saying they want to be reluctant shareholders." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	24	3843	GM vice chairman Robert Lutz said the administration is taking appropriate measures to help an industry vital to the US economy, and praised Obama's Automotive Task Force. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	25	4024	"Their prime goal is not to gain government control of the automobile industry," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	26	4123	"They absolutely don't want that ... their number one goal is to make us successful. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	27	4208	There finally is a realization that our country cannot remain economically strong and militarily strong and have a global impact if it’s not backed up by wealth-producing industries." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	0	58	GM to lose prestigious spot on Dow 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	1	168	General Motors' fall from grace is not yet complete. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	2	221	The firm's expected bankruptcy would spell its eviction from the Dow Jones coveted list of 30 top US companies, of which GM has been a pillar since 1925. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	3	384	Even if GM's court filing has not yet been inked, speculation is rife about which firm might take its place on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, as the former behemoth's share price tumbled 47 percent last week. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	4	605	GM's shares fell to 75 cents each on Friday, well below the one dollar minimum for listing on the New York-based exchange. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	5	737	It is a confluence of factors that means GM will suffer the same fate as AIG. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	6	815	In September, the insurance giant was removed from the Dow Jones index two days after its nationalization, replaced by Kraft Foods. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	7	956	"Once a company files for bankruptcy protection it is disqualified from being one of the 30 Dow components," said Dow spokesperson Sybille Reitz. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	8	1111	"We are aware of GM's situation and are taking steps accordingly. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	9	1177	We have been following the situation closely." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	10	1233	There is great competition to replace GM on the venerable list, which has served as a bellwether for US business since it was launched in 1896. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	11	1386	One solution could be to replace GM with its rival Ford -- which has so far managed to escape the crisis without government aid. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	12	1524	But Ford's share price is far from stellar, trading at around 5.75 dollars. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	13	1600	According to John Ogg of 247wallst.com, that makes the firm -- which had previously been a member of the elite club -- an unlikely inductee. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	14	1750	One of the more frequently cited names is that of Wall Street darling Goldman Sachs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	15	1844	The investment giant should be one of the first to pay back government loans, thanks to a share price of more than 144 dollars. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	16	1981	Nicholas Colas, head of investment strategy at the BNY ConvergEx Group, said that makes Goldman Sachs a favorite. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	17	2104	It may also have been helped by AIG's departure. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	18	2162	During the AIG shakeout in September the Dow Jones group noted that the exit of one financial firm meant that that economically vital sector was under- represented. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	19	2336	But there are other contenders. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	20	2368	From the technology sector Apple, Google, Cisco and Oracle are mentioned as possible replacements. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	21	2476	Google's candidature runs into the difficulty that its share price -- at over 400 dollars a piece -- may skew the index. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	22	2606	And technology stocks are already well represented by heavyweight IBM. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	23	2686	A recent poll by CNBC has further muddied the picture. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	24	2741	The financial news provider asked customers who should replace GM. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	25	2808	The response was Abbott Labs, a pharmaceuticals firm. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	26	2871	From the biotech field, Monsanto is an outsider. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	27	2920	Owen Patrick of Deutsche Bank pointed out that Monsanto was an important member of another index, the Standard and Poor's 500. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	28	3056	"It is a little smaller in market cap," said BNY's Colas, "and not as well known, but its technology and competitive advantage would be unique in the Dow." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	29	3221	If the GM change has been keenly anticipated, that is because change on the Dow is rare. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	30	3319	Only six firms have come in this decade, with three in 2008 including Kraft -- Bank of America and Chevron replaced Altria and Honeywell. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	31	3466	According to Ogg the index's managers may use the opportunity to dump other listings hit by the financial crisis. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	32	3589	Citigroup, now trading at four dollars a share, must feel its head is on the chopping block. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	0	58	Malaysia's Islamic party at a crossroads 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	1	178	A power struggle in Malaysia's Islamic party will be put to the test in leadership polls this week which pit hardline clerics against young moderates who want to rebrand the party. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	2	368	The Pan-Malaysia Islamic Party (PAS) has enjoyed a surge in popularity thanks to deep public disillusionment with the Barisan Nasional coalition that has governed the multiracial country for half a century. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	3	584	PAS has formed an unlikely alliance with two other opposition parties which has stuck together despite wide differences in their ideologies, giving them a chance to unseat the coalition in the next elections due in several years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	4	823	But the PAS general assembly on June 5-7 will lay bare the dilemma at the party's core -- whether to swing back to its hardline roots or to put on a more moderate face to continue winning back support after some barren years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	5	1058	"The party is at a threshold -- whether it can transcend its history of catering largely to Muslims and put in place a model that everyone in the country including non-Muslims can accept," said pollster Ibrahim Suffian. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	6	1287	"They need to be able to articulate issues relating to the economy, security, international trade... to not only look after your hereafter, but look after your here and today," said Ibrahim, from Merdeka Centre research. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	7	1517	Some 60 percent of Malaysians are Muslim Malays, but the population includes large ethnic Chinese and Indian communities, and if PAS wants to break out beyond its niche it needs to attract support from minorities. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	8	1740	Curiously, despite pushing for the creation of an Islamic state and the introduction of "hudud" laws like chopping off thieves' hands, PAS has won the trust and support of many non-Muslims. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	9	1939	Chinese and Indian voters have enthusiastically supported PAS candidates in seats where they stood for the Pakatan Rakyat opposition alliance, and thousands have joined PAS "Supporters' Clubs" around the country. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	10	2161	Much of the attraction stems from PAS's reputation as a clean party untainted by the corruption which is endemic in the ruling coalition. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	11	2308	And in northern Kelantan state, where it has long been in power, minorities have few complaints and are not obliged to observe local bylaws that discourage skimpy clothing and high heels. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	12	2505	Reforms introduced before landmark 2008 elections, when the Pakatan Rakyat snatched a third of parliamentary seats in an unprecedented performance, reversed a decline that had seen PAS decimated in 2004 polls. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	13	2724	"They stopped talking about wanting to impose stricter sharia laws and they had much more moderate faces in the party, people who were professionals and able to converse in English," said Ibrahim. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	14	2930	But this rebranding exercise is now in jeopardy with a vote for top leadership posts, including the deputy presidency, which will see a clash between incumbent Nasharuddin Mat Isa and challenger Husam Musa. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	15	3146	Husam is an economist who typifies the party's new generation of educated professionals, while Nasharuddin is closely identified with the party's conservative president Abdul Hadi Awang. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	16	3342	Husam is an ally of PAS's iconic spiritual leader Nik Abdul Aziz Nik Mat, a quirky figure who is a highly respected religious leader and also a big supporter of opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	17	3545	Nasharuddin meanwhile played a leading role in "secret" talks last year with the ruling party UMNO -- which leads the Barisan Nasional coalition -- that were hugely controversial within the party. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	18	3751	Observers say that if Nasharuddin retains his post, the fragile bonds between the opposition partners will begin to erode, jeopardising its ability to challenge the coalition. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	19	3936	"PAS is at a crossroads now. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	20	3965	This meeting will see whether PAS is inclined to have a good relationship with UMNO or have a good relationship with its opposition partners," a party insider told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	21	4143	He said that a rebuke to Husam would also send out a negative message to non- Muslims that it remains the "party of the ulamas", the elderly cohort of clerics who have historically dominated the party. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	22	4354	"As a political party PAS has to go with the (reform) approach, that which is accepted by the Malaysian people. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	23	4466	During the last general election PAS had a lot of support from non-Muslims and it has to maintain that," he said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0416	0	58	Danish Tiananmen sculptor denied entry to Hong Kong 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0416	1	186	A Danish sculptor who flew to Hong Kong to protest the bloody crackdown on pro- democracy protests in Beijing 20 years ago has been refused entry to the city, an official and a legislator said Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0416	2	396	Jens Galschiot, whose sculpture commemorating those who died in the 1989 military crackdown, "Pillar of Shame," is displayed at Hong Kong University, was stopped by officials Saturday, an immigration spokesman said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0416	3	621	Albert Ho, the chairman of the Democratic Party and a lawyer, said the Dane was detained for five hours before being put on a flight to Zurich late Saturday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0416	4	788	Galschiot, who was also refused entry to the city ahead of the Beijing Olympics last year, had planned to join the annual June 4 vigil to mark the anniversary of the crackdown. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0416	5	974	He was also planning to repair his sculpture and donate two more. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0416	6	1049	"We are looking at the possibility of legal action following the decision," Ho told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0416	7	1138	Ho had been allowed to see Galschiot during his detention. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0416	8	1206	Other members of his family and a filmmaker accompanying them were allowed to pass through immigration. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0416	9	1319	The Danish Consulate was not immediately available for comment. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0416	10	1392	The immigration department spokesman said it had acted in accordance with the law.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	0	58	Insein prison: Myanmar's 'silent killing field' 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	1	180	Described by inmates as a "hell" where beatings are common and disease is rife, Myanmar's Insein Prison, where Aung San Suu Kyi is on trial, is the brutal symbol of the ruling junta's repression. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	2	385	The Nobel laureate has spent the past three weeks incarcerated in a so-called "guest house" at the jail on the outskirts of Yangon while her trial takes place behind closed doors at the notorious compound. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	3	600	Her party has expressed concerns for her health after she suffered leg cramps in recent days while at the prison. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	4	714	The authorities say she is receiving medical care. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	5	774	But if Aung San Suu Kyi has been kept in relatively bearable conditions at the prison -- which was built by former colonial power Britain -- for hundreds of other political prisoners it is the heart of Myanmar's darkness. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	6	1005	"It's like a hell where people really suffer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	7	1051	It's some kind of silent 'killing field,'" Bo Kyi, who spent seven years in the jail following a failed student uprising in 1988, told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	8	1200	Several political prisoners told of how they suffered bruising weeks-long interrogations at the hands of the junta's jailers at Insein. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	9	1345	Bo Kyi said during one round of questioning he was whipped with a rubber cord as he lay on his stomach and counted 150 lashes before he lost consciousness and awoke in a solitary cell. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	10	1539	He said he was then forced to assume different positions for hour-long periods while shackled in chains with a bar between his legs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	11	1681	The heavily secured Insein is home to many of the 2,100 political prisoners which the United Nations says are held in Myanmar's prisons, often on spurious sentences of up to 60 years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	12	1874	At least 139 political detainees have died in detention in the country since 1988, several of them in Insein, according to the Assistance Association for Political Prisoners of Burma (AAPPB), co-founded by Bo Kyi. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	13	2097	Details of conditions inside the secretive jail emerge mostly from former prisoners, although Tomas Okea Quintana, the UN Special Rapporteur on Myanmar, visited the prison for four hours in February and met five inmates. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	14	2327	He said after his visit that many detainees suffered from a lack of medical care during imprisonment. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	15	2438	Former prisoner Aung Myo Naing, who spent more than eight years there, said that each cell in Insein is 8 by 11 feet (2.5 by 3.5 metres), furnished with two bamboo mats and two uncovered toilet buckets. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	16	2650	"Insein Prison is a deadly torture camp," the 41-year-old said, describing one period of about 45 days when he was kept in solitary confinement and forbidden to read, write or bathe. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	17	2842	Past prisoners have described novel methods of communicating during these times, scratching messages to one another on cigarette filter papers and feeding them through holes in prison walls. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	18	3042	Inmates are given 15 minutes outside of the cell daily to shower, but they have no soap and no spare clothes to change into. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	19	3176	Many prisoners are starving -- their rations of food consist of boiled water with a few sparse vegetables, fish paste and occasional rations of meat along with overcooked rice, while water is not purified. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	20	3391	The conditions mean that diseases such as tuberculosis and hepatitis B are rife, while joint pains, eyesight problems and mental illness are commonplace. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	21	3554	But access to a doctor is rare. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	22	3595	"They give you aspirins and another drug for sneezing, whatever illness you've got," said Aung Myo Thein, whose elder brother was also imprisoned and now suffers severe depression. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	23	3785	Due to dirty needles, medical treatment can itself be hazardous. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	24	3859	Last year media watchdog Reporters Without Borders said that poet Aung Than, a member of Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy, was probably infected with the HIV virus when he was forcibly injected in Insein prison hospital. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	25	4096	Many other prominent prisoners have been denied access to healthcare and have been moved since October 2008 to jails hundreds of miles from their families. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	26	4261	The International Committee of the Red Cross made its last visit to Insein Prison in November 2005, and two months later suspended its prison visits saying it could not fulfil its independent, impartial mandate.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0421	18	2724	"Now is the time for Japan to say what kind of world it would like to create, not to adapt itself to the given circumstances as it has done" since its defeat in World World II, he said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	2	377	The country logged unexpectedly strong 5.8 percent growth in the final quarter to March 2009, against forecasts of 5.0 percent, figures late last week showed, prompting analysts to say the economy had turned the corner.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	5	883	But the country of nearly 1.2 billion people is performing far better than many others caught in the global slump, thanks to its vast, resilient domestic market, hefty government spending and aggressive rate cuts, analysts say.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	11	2208	Next year, economists expect expansion of eight percent.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	19	3608	But Mukherjee said his "top priority" was "reviving the growth momentum" and helping the poor and he would step up spending even if this meant scant progress in closing India's yawning fiscal deficit, which at 6.2 percent is at a seven- year peak.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	2	354	"Angola is one of the last great emerging market opportunities," one European man told AFP between sips of whisky. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	3	478	"I don't care about the logistical problems as long as the solutions and rewards are there -- I'm in this for the long term to make money." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	4	627	Thanks to high oil prices and a peacetime construction frenzy, Angola has enjoyed annual double-digit growth since a 27-year civil war ended in 2002 to become one of the world's fastest growing economies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	5	841	Growth is set to slow this year, but interest from international investors has not abated with a recent flurry of high profile trade delegations, all hoping to get a piece of the action. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	6	1037	The government's response to falling commodity prices, which threaten public spending aimed at Angola's poor majority, is diversification into areas such as agriculture and manufacturing.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	12	2097	"The amount of time it takes to get to Angola from the US, via Europe or via South Africa, has an impact on trade and the new flight will definitely be a catalyst for investment."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	14	2381	"Angola is a country which is really moving," explained Nigel Page, senior vice president of Emirates in Americas and Africa. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	15	2516	"We predict that there will be a lot of business exchanges between Luanda and Dubai and this route will channel more companies into Angola from the east." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	16	2680	There is already plenty of Asian investment in Angola, particularly from China which holds a number of key construction contracts, including four 2010 Africa Cup of Nations football stadiums. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	17	2881	China's interest in Angola has aroused concern in the west, especially as a number of the loans have been oil backed, but Alex Vines, of the London-based think tank Chatham House, believes the Sino-Angolan relationship may be waning. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	18	3124	"From a geo-strategic point of view, Angola wants to woo lots of different investment, not just from China," he told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	19	3255	"And that's why we've seen Dos Santos making these high profile visits to Europe and these other trade trips being invited to Angola." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	20	3399	Despite predicting a three-percent contraction in 2009, World Bank economist Ricardo Gazel said: "Angola's economy is still in a much better position than most and medium and long term, the prospects are very good. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	21	3623	"There is a lot of investment interest, particularly in the non-petroleum sector which is good for diversifying the economy and for the economy as a whole." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	22	3789	For businesses hoping to break into the Angolan market however, it's not easy and good contacts go a long way. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	23	3909	The World Bank's Doing Business Report ranks Angola as one of the hardest places to set up a company with 68 days needed to start a business, although this has halved since 2008. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	24	4097	But, big on capital if low on know-how, Angola has been spreading the word about investment opportunities and it seems the world is listening.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	0	58	Bordeaux bets on top quality but cheap 2008 vintage 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	1	193	After months of gloom, Bordeaux wine traders are hoping the 2008 vintage will revive the market after steep price cuts and rave reviews from the world's most influential connoisseur. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	2	385	The southwestern French region's rarest wines are sold every spring as a futures commodity, 12 months prior to bottling. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	3	506	With the world gripped by recession, many had been fearing financial disaster. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	4	594	The futures sale only concerns a tiny percentage of the 800 million bottles the Bordeaux region produces annually, but the prices of the top 20 wines help determine the public perception of the quality of the vintage. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	5	821	This year, the big wine estates brought prices down sharply, opening the way for traders to target middle market wine drinkers after a period when the finest wines were priced for sale to only the richest speculators. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	6	1048	As Patrick Bernard, owner of wine merchant powerhouse Millesima, explained: "If the top 20 wines double or triple their prices as they did in 2005, all of Bordeaux wine is perceived as expensive. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	7	1253	"The first wine on the market was Angelus, one of those 20 wines, and they cut their price by 40 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	8	1359	A few days later, the First Growths came out with a 45 percent decrease and then Yquem with a 65 percent decrease." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	9	1484	Other premium wines were released at the same time to maintain momentum. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	10	1557	Leoville Barton dropped its ex-cellar price to 23 euros and sold out within a few hours. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	11	1655	"It was much better than I expected," said Lilian Barton, co-owner of the legendary estates Chateaux Leoville Barton and Langoa Barton, and director of her family wine merchant, Les Vins Fins Anthony Barton. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	12	1872	In addition to dropping their prices, the chateaux had hoped to demonstrate their independence from US wine critic Robert Parker, nicknamed the "Million Dollar Nose" for his influence on the market. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	13	2080	Parker is a champion of Bordeaux's wines, but many in the industry feel that he wields too much power with his rankings, and three-quarters of the wines were put on sale before he had given his verdict. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	14	2292	The demonstration of defiance was only partly successful, at best. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	15	2368	Several sources said that sales prior to the release of Parker's ratings, with the exception of a few star buys, were subdued. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	16	2495	The tempo changed when Parker awarded the vintage spectacular ratings. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	17	2575	"The buyers went berserk," said Barton. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	18	2624	Clients who had pleaded poverty in early April suddenly found the wherewithal to buy on futures. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	19	2730	Despite annoyance with the fickle importers, Barton, Anson, Bernard and others were relieved to see the return of traditional customers who had been pushed out of the market in recent years by skyrocketing prices. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	20	2953	The vintage was very good and there was a dramatic drop in price -- buyers are stocking up for customers who buy wine to drink rather than to invest. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	21	3112	"This was the vintage to buy for the consumer," enthused Bernard. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	22	3187	Unlike nearly all of the other 400 wine merchants, Millesima, with annual revenues of 52 million euros, sells directly to the consumer in 11 European countries and America. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	23	3369	"Direct sales to European consumers has been good. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	24	3420	There's no currency problem and they haven't been able to afford it over the last few years." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	25	3523	Bernard will buy 35,000 cases this year, a 10 percent increase over last year even though most chateaux are offering customers only 80 percent of their usual allocations because of a small crop. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	26	3727	While the 2008 futures campaign is slowly drawing to a close, there is little doubt that for many it succeeded in resuscitating not only sales but the image of Bordeaux wine as a consumer product. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	27	3933	Already merchants and winegrowers are looking forward to Vinexpo, the International Wine and Spirits Exhibition held from June 21 to 25, with 45,000 professionals expected to attend. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	0	58	Eurozone interest rate locked, new steps on tap: analysts 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	1	192	The main eurozone interest rate is probably locked in at 1.0 percent for now, but credit flows remain weak and the European Central Bank will detail this week new ways to get money flowing again. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	2	397	The ECB will also release Thursday its latest staff forecasts for growth and inflation in the 16-nation bloc, with a downward revision likely for the former owing to a disastrous first quarter in its leading economies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	3	625	With interest rates most likely on hold for a while, "the focus has shifted to any developments regarding unconventional policies," said Capital Economics economist Jennifer McKeown. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	4	817	The ECB has already said it will buy 60 billion euros' (85 billion dollars') worth of covered, or collateralised, bonds, a move that should help restore cash flows in French, German and Spanish markets where such instruments are traded most widely. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	5	1075	Details are expected after a meeting of the bank's governing council. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	6	1154	But the amount corresponds to just 0.6 percent of the eurozone's gross domestic product, McKeown noted, whereas bolder moves by the US Federal Reserve and Bank of England are worth around 10 percent of their respective GDP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	7	1387	It also remains to be seen whether the ECB will "sterilise" the purchases by issuing its own debt or selling other assets, or whether it will just print new money, a move that could fuel inflation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	8	1594	The bank's priority is to keep inflation just below 2.0 percent, but it now faces the prospect of a broad-based fall in prices that could end in a deflationary spiral which could strangle economic activity. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	9	1810	If businesses and individuals become convinced that prices will fall further, they postpone purchases, causing production to fall and raising unemployment, which can depress prices further. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	10	2009	Eurozone inflation hit a record low of zero in May, European Union statistics showed, and will likely turn negative in coming months owing to comparisons with the same period last year when oil prices spiked to record highs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	11	2243	But UniCredit economist Marco Valli said: "We don't think the ECB will be overly impressed" by the development, which has been forecast for several months. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	12	2408	ECB president Jean-Claude Trichet has stressed that short term price volatility is not a factor in the bank's decisions, and with oil prices on the rise again, a deflationary episode is unlikely to last long. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	13	2626	"The recent strong rally in oil prices makes the inflation picture more uncertain than just a couple of weeks ago," Valli said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	14	2763	"The central bank will continue to see the risk of deflation as very low," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	15	2857	The ECB can also point to indications that the eurozone's first recession has probably passed its trough even though the European Commission still expects the economy to contract by 1.9 percent this year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	16	3071	That leaves the thorny problem of credit growth, which according to the bank's figures continued to slow sharply in April. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	17	3203	"There is no easing in the very tight credit conditions that are facing companies and individuals," noted Howard Archer at IHS Global Insight. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	18	3355	"Tighter credit conditions are a serious handicap to recovery prospects in the eurozone," he said, and raise pressure on the ECB "to take additional 'non- standard' measures." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	19	3540	Commerzbank analyst Rainer Guntermann felt "the ECB has not yet closed the door to more easing measures," but that an expansion of the already announced bond purchases in June was unlikely. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	0	58	Germany rescues Opel, for now 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	1	161	Germany has ensured that Opel's tens of thousands of workers will still have a job on Monday when its once-mighty US parent General Motors, as is expected, makes history and files for bankruptcy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	2	366	But Chancellor Angela Merkel's decision to support with taxpayers' money a Kremlin-backed rescue may come back to haunt her, and could fail to prevent Opel crashing and burning further down the road, experts say. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	3	588	"All this seems to rest on a very fragile base. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	4	636	Let's say there is a 60 or 70 percent chance that it won't work," Juergen Pieper, an automotive analyst at Metzler Bank, told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	5	776	In a mammoth effort over recent months climaxing in a frenzy of activity last week, the German government agreed in the early hours of Saturday morning to back a takeover of Opel by a consortium formed around Canada's Magna. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	6	1010	Under the deal, GM would keep 35 percent of the company and Opel's workers would retain 10 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	7	1110	Magna, which makes auto parts, would hold a 20 percent stake and state-owned Russian lender Sberbank 35 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	8	1232	Government sources told AFP that Germany would act as guarantor for around three billion euros (4.2 billion dollars) worth of loans, and the government would also itself make an emergency loan of 1.5 billion euros to Opel. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	9	1464	Magna meanwhile, which until recently was relatively unknown outside the auto industry, has pledged to cough up 300 million euros to keep the cash-starved Opel alive in the coming weeks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	10	1660	The Canadian firm, which thrashed out an eleventh-hour agreement with GM executives in a luxury Berlin hotel on Friday, has pledged to keep all Opel's German factories open and limit job cuts there to around 2,500. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	11	1884	But across Europe as a whole, where GM employs some 50,000 people including 7,000 in Spain and 4,700 at Britain's Vauxhall, the picture may be less rosy with Magna saying it plans to lay off one in five workers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	12	2105	Last week Germany came under pressure from Britain and Belgium not to save German jobs at the expense of workers elsewhere, and on Saturday Britain's biggest trade union Unite voiced concern about the fate of Vauxhall workers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	13	2341	It was also unclear whether Magna's intention to start making Opel cars at a factory in Russia owned by precious metals tycoon Oleg Deripaska's GAZ automaker would mean some production will be taken away from plants in the European Union. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	14	2589	Russian involvement also raises eyebrows because it strengthens the already strong business ties -- most notably in gas -- between Berlin and Moscow. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	15	2739	Critics say that these ties make Germany too soft on the Kremlin. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	16	2814	For analysts, it was September's elections in Germany that helped win Merkel over to Russian involvement. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	17	2929	"Money doesn't smell at election time," said Andrew Wilson at the European Council of Foreign Relations think tank. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	18	3054	Magna and its Russian backers have their work cut out making the deal work, with Opel part of a global automotive industry that was already facing huge challenges even before the world economy hit the skids last year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	19	3281	Frank Schwope, an analyst at Germany's NordLB bank, predicted that the Canadian- Russian investors "will try everything, and then fail and Opel will be insolvent in two or three years." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	20	3476	Magna also has very little experience making cars -- unlike Fiat, which also wanted to snap up Opel but then got cold feet -- and the financial details of the deal are unclear. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	21	3662	Merkel admitted on Saturday that the road ahead is a rocky one. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	22	3735	"For Opel and Magna, the work is now just beginning and there are several difficulties still to overcome," she said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	23	3861	But cynics say that for the chancellor and her partners in the governing coalition, even if Opel does end up collapsing further down the road, it is mission accomplished: Opel will not be issue in September's vote.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	0	58	Progress in fighting lung cancer at specialist summit 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	1	195	Cancer specialists, gathered for an annual meeting, are reporting progress in the fight against lung cancer, the most common and deadliest form of cancer, but little progress in treating colorectal cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	2	410	Doctors and researchers at the 45th gathering of the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) -- the world's main cancer conference -- on Saturday learned of two studies showing progress in the battle against lung cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	3	645	The first study showed how the combination of two anti-cancer treatments following standard chemotherapy can slow the advance of lung cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	4	796	Patients treated with a combination of Tarceva, sold by the Swiss drugmaker Roche, and Avastin, a drug by Roche's Genentech unit, saw their cancer growth slow more than a control group treated with Avastin. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	5	1012	More than 750 patients were randomized to receive Avastin and a placebo, or Avastin and Tarceva. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	6	1109	Those in the Tarceva group survived an average of 4.8 months before the cancer started growing again, compared to 3.7 months for the control group, said Vincent Miller, the study's main author. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	7	1312	The numbers translated to a 29 percent reduced risk of disease progression for patients who took a combination of Tarceva and Avastin. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	8	1456	"This is the first study to show that adding erlotinib (Tarceva) to maintenance therapy with bevacizumab (Avastin) delays disease progression in patients who have already received bevacizumab as part of their initial chemotherapy," said Miller. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	9	1710	A second study with 663 patients with advance lung cancer were given the drug Alimta, from US pharmaceutical Eli Lilly, which blocks cell growth. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	10	1865	Preliminary results showed that patients who took the drug lived 26 percent longer compared to a control group that took a placebo: 13.4 months against 10.6 months. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	11	2039	As in the first study, all the patients had already received four standard chemotherapy sessions. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	12	2146	"This study will change the overall standard of care," said Chandra Belani, the deputy director of the Penn State Cancer Institute, as she presented the research. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	13	2318	"Maintenance therapy with Alimta (permetrexed) offers a new paradigm for patients who have advanced lung cancer, because it has a low toxicity and can be given on an ongoing basis over a prolonged period of time to extend patients' lives," she said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	14	2577	However there were few advances to report in the fight against colorectal cancer, the fourth most common in the United States and the second deadliest type of cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	15	2753	Research on 2,710 patients with Phase Three colorectal cancer taking the drug Avastine along with standard chemotherapy treatment showed no difference in the survival rate or the recurrence of the tumor after three and a half years when compared to those not taking the drug. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	16	3038	Another study conducted in Italy among 747 patients with advanced colorectal cancer showed that the drug Eloxatine from the French firm Sanofi did not reduce the size of the tumor when combined with standard treatment used ahead of cancer surgery.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0438	2	383	The family's lawyer said that religious authorities insisted Mohan Singh, a 41 -year-old art director who died of a heart attack last Monday, had died a Muslim -- a claim the family disputes.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0438	10	1570	"He wouldn't be able to do so if he is a Muslim," he said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0438	12	1845	The tussles have raised allegations that the country of 27 million people is being "Islamised" and that the rights of the ethnic Chinese and Indian minorities are being eroded.
