AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	0	58	Key Tiananmen dissident still defiant, 20 years on 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	1	183	Former top Chinese Communist official Bao Tong was purged for supporting the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square, but he says his frustrations with the system started decades before. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	2	393	"China's people have wasted 60 years," Bao, now one of the country's top political dissidents, told AFP recently -- before authorities moved him out of Beijing to wait out Thursday's 20th anniversary of the deadly crackdown. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	3	627	His harsh assessment of the history of the People's Republic of China, founded in October 1949, is one few ordinary Chinese would dare to make. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	4	780	But the 76-year-old Bao, once a top aide to former Chinese leader Zhao Ziyang, is not your average citizen. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	5	897	He has spent the past 20 years either in jail, under house arrest or facing other restrictions in his small west Beijing flat, just one block from a major road where protesters battled tanks and troops. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	6	1109	He sees no sign of political openness on the horizon and says Beijing's failure to come clean on the events of June 3-4, 1989 and give justice to victims has been a key factor stunting democratic development. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	7	1327	"It has had a seriously negative impact. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	8	1368	It has made China a country with no voice.... a country in which no one can demand fairness," he said in the interview at his apartment. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	9	1514	"I am a sample on display," Bao says with a smirk, charging the government only allows foreign journalists to interview him to give the impression of openness, while preventing anything he says from being disseminated in China. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	10	1751	Bao was dragged down along with Zhao, who was ousted from his position as general secretary of the Communist Party for sympathising with the student protesters who had rallied for weeks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	11	1947	Zhao had opposed the use of force against the demonstrators, but was overruled by party hardliners. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	12	2047	Hundreds, and possibly thousands, were killed in the army crackdown. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	13	2125	Bao, who once directed a top Communist party political reform office, is still lean and energetic. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	14	2233	He now spends much of his time doing interviews with or fielding calls from foreign media on a phone whose ring tone is the Disney theme "It's a Small World." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	15	2401	Bao said China's current leaders bear no blame for what happened in Tiananmen Square -- and could earn great praise both at home and abroad on this anniversary by being more forthcoming. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	16	2597	"They are still the nation's leaders and I hope they can openly tell the Chinese people and the world what happened," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	17	2733	But the party's unwillingness to admit any mistakes will prevent that and the Chinese people are too intimidated to demand such honesty, he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	18	2889	Much of the blame lies with the rest of the world for refusing to push China to heal the wounds, said Bao, adding that other countries were increasingly hesitant to rile China due to its growing economic and diplomatic clout. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	19	3124	"Not wanting to offend China means they cannot help China, cannot help China's people attain their own rights, and cannot help the world community gain a reliable, stable, peaceful member," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	20	3332	"This is not a good thing." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	21	3369	As the Communist Party gears up to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China on October 1, Bao said there was little to celebrate. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	22	3548	The party wasted a lifetime with collectivisation of the economy launched in 1953, only to come full circle with today's run-away capitalism. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	23	3699	"(We) have come back to the original point. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	24	3743	The work of 1.3 billion people has been wasted for 56 years," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	25	3823	"This is a crime greater than (the Tiananmen crackdown)." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	26	3890	Bao expressed delight with the May release in English of Zhao's memoirs, put together from secret tape recordings the deposed leader made while under house arrest. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	27	4054	His son, Bao Pu, is publishing the Chinese version of the book. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	28	4127	He said he hoped the book, likely to be banned in China, could somehow be distributed in the country and spark debate. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	29	4255	But he admitted the ghosts of Tiananmen would not likely be laid to rest any time soon due to the nature of a government for which he wishes he had never worked. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	30	4426	"I regret that I only realised all of this 20 years ago. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	31	4483	Why couldn't I have realised it 40 years ago or 60 years ago?" 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	32	4546	he lamented.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	0	58	Tiananmen: Six weeks of protests, and then a crackdown 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	1	187	In April 1989, young Chinese with dreams of democracy staged an unprecedented wave of protests after the death of former Communist Party leader Hu Yaobang, a popular reformer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	2	372	The Tiananmen movement lasted six weeks before being violently quashed by the army, leaving hundreds, and possibly thousands, dead. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	3	513	Here is a timeline of the main events: 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	4	561	April 1989 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	5	581	- 15: Death of Hu Yaobang, who had been dismissed two years earlier. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	6	659	- 17: First student protest on Tiananmen Square, to lay a wreath in honour of Hu, adorned with pro-democracy slogans. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	7	786	- 18: The students issue a list of demands to the government that includes freedom of speech and democratic elections. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	8	914	- 22: Hu's official funeral takes place at the Great Hall of the People on Tiananmen Square, where 200,000 students are gathered. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	9	1053	- 25: Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, says the protest movement seeks to topple the Communist Party -- a claim that forms the basis of an explosive editorial in the official People's Daily newspaper the next day. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	10	1278	- 27: Huge student demonstrations take place in Beijing, and protests erupt across the country, including in towns that had been calm until that time. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	11	1438	May 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	12	1451	- 4: The anniversary of the patriotic movement of May 4, 1919 triggers a new mass demonstration in Beijing and in 50 other towns. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	13	1581	The head of the Communist Party, Zhao Ziyang, urges dialogue. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	14	1652	- 13: Students launch the occupation of Tiananmen Square and a hunger strike. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	15	1739	- 15: A historic visit by then Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev for the normalisation of Sino-Soviet ties is completely disrupted. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	16	1878	- 17: About 1.2 million students, workers, civil servants, and intellectuals protest in Beijing. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	17	1975	Major demonstrations take place in most provinces across the country. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	18	2054	- 18: The conservative Prime Minister Li Peng attempts to start a dialogue with student leaders. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	19	2160	- 19: Zhao goes to Tiananmen Square, and pleads with the hunger strikers to leave, with tears in his eyes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	20	2267	It is his last public appearance. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	21	2310	- 20: Martial law is declared, and army troops that are summoned either stop or are stopped by barricades. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	22	2426	- 26: Zhao is purged from the Communist leadership, and put under house arrest on the 28th. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	23	2527	- 29: Fine arts students erect a statue -- the 'Goddess of Democracy' -- in front of the portrait of Mao Zedong, the founder of communist China, on the square, where students are growing tired and divided. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	24	2742	June: 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	25	2757	- 1st: An official report brings up for the first time the notion of a "counter- revolutionary riot." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	26	2868	- 2: The Communist Party's leadership decides to clear the square. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	27	2944	- 3: Students and citizens block military vehicles at Beijing's major intersections. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	28	3029	That night, messages broadcast by loudspeaker call on the population to clear the roads. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	29	3118	The students equip themselves with sticks and makeshift weapons. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	30	3192	- June 3-4: The army evacuates Tiananmen Square without firing shots. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	31	3262	Soldiers flanked by tanks open fire elsewhere. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	32	3309	Fighting on roads ensues. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	33	3335	Hundreds, and possibly thousands, are killed. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	34	3390	- 5-20: China is widely condemned abroad and is targeted with sanctions. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	35	3472	- 24: Jiang Zemin, the future Chinese president, is officially made General Secretary of the Communist Party, replacing Zhao. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0444	0	58	Five Colombian soldiers killed fighting leftist rebels 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0444	1	186	Five soldiers were killed and nine wounded in fighting with leftist guerrillas in central Colombia, the army said late Saturday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0444	2	324	Fighting broke out Saturday morning in a remote rural area in the municipality of Puerto Rico, in Meta province, when soldiers with the Joint Task Force Omega -- specializing in anti-guerrilla jungle warfare -- came upon a Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) rebel camp, the army statement read. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0444	3	639	The wounded soldiers were rushed to a military hospital and a civilian hospital in the town of Granada, the statement read, offering no details on their condition. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0444	4	812	On Friday, FARC rebels killed five soldiers and wounded six others in fighting in the jungle province of Guaviare. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0444	5	927	Five FARC rebels were also killed in the fighting, the army said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	0	58	Key dates in post-Tiananmen China 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	1	166	The following is a list of key dates in the history of China, following the crushing of the Tiananmen pro-democracy protests by army troops in June 1989: 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	2	329	1989 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	3	343	After 10 years of market reform and opening to the outside world, China finds itself again isolated internationally and the target of sanctions after the Tiananmen crackdown. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	4	518	Arms embargoes by the United States and the European Union are implemented and remain in place 20 years later. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	5	638	1990 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	6	652	Deng Xiaoping formally retires from all of his official positions, but remains influential from behind the scenes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	7	776	1992 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	8	790	Deng embarks on his "southern tour" which relaunches the economic reforms that have been paralysed since 1989. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	9	910	The government calls for students staying overseas to return to China no matter what their attitude on past political events has been. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	10	1054	1993 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	11	1068	Jiang Zemin, who was named head of the Communist Party after the crushing of the protests in 1989, is made the nation's president in March. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	12	1217	1997 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	13	1231	February 19: Deng dies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	14	1264	July 1: The British colony of Hong Kong is returned to China. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	15	1335	2001 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	16	1349	Beijing wins the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	17	1413	December 11: China becomes a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO).

AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	20	1581	2003

AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	22	1644	October 15: China launches its first man into outer space.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	24	1821	The government tried to cover up the initial outbreak of the epidemic in the southern part of the country.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	0	58	Tiananmen Square: 10 key figures 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	1	165	The following are brief profiles of the 10 people -- students, politicians and others -- who played key roles in the drama that unfolded in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in 1989: 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	2	350	THE STUDENTS 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	3	372	-- Wang Dan, the moderate (born 1969). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	4	411	A student from the elite Peking University, he was replaced as leader of the movement by more radical protesters. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	5	525	After his arrest in July 1989, he was sentenced in 1991 to four years in jail. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	6	604	He was released in 1993, but arrested again in 1995 on subversion charges and sentenced to another 11 years in prison. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	7	723	In 1998, he was deported to the United States. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	8	770	He continues his campaign for democracy in China in the west. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	9	841	-- Chai Ling, the muse (born 1966). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	10	877	The tiny woman was known as the "general commander" of the protest headquarters at Tiananmen Square. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	11	978	After the crackdown, she was put on the list of the 21 most wanted students, but after 10 months on the run she managed to escape to France. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	12	1119	She now lives in the United States, where she works as an Internet entrepreneur. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	13	1209	-- Wu'er Kaixi, the rebel (born 1968). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	14	1248	A member of the Uighur ethnic minority, he became a celebrity overnight after he interrupted Premier Li Peng during a meeting between student leaders and politicians aired live on state television on May 18, 1989. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	15	1462	He was able to flee China after the June 4 crackdown and now lives in Taiwan. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	16	1549	THE POLITICIANS 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	17	1574	-- Deng Xiaoping, the patriarch (1904-1997). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	18	1619	The most influential of the leaders, the chairman of the Central Military Commission and father of economic reform tilted the balance in favour of a hard line and ordered the army to fire on protesters after six weeks of rallies that left the government paralysed. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	19	1893	-- Zhao Ziyang, the disgraced reformer (1919-2005). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	20	1945	As general secretary of the Communist Party, he supported dialogue between the government and the protesters. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	21	2055	On May 19, 1989, he visited the students on Tiananmen Square, and, in tears, urged them to leave. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	22	2153	This was his last public appearance. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	23	2190	He was relieved of his duties in June and placed under house arrest until his death. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	24	2284	-- Li Peng, the hardliner (born 1928). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	25	2323	He was made prime minister in 1988 and also a member of the Standing Committee of the Communist Party's Politburo, the heart of political power in China. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	26	2477	Announcing martial law on May 19, he paved the way for the crackdown. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	27	2556	THE INTELLECTUALS 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	28	2583	-- Fang Lizhi, the veteran dissident (born 1936). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	29	2633	Even if this famous astrophysicist did not participate directly in the Tiananmen movement, his ideas were a clear inspiration. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	30	2760	He had been thrown out of the Communist Party in 1987, and shortly after the crackdown in 1989, the authorities issued an arrest order against him. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	31	2908	He escaped into the US embassy, and was granted political asylum in the United States in 1991. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	32	3012	-- Liu Xiaobo, the mediator (born 1955). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	33	3053	The author was popular among the young for his criticism of traditional Chinese values, and further joined the students in a hunger strike on Tiananmen Square. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	34	3213	On the night of June 3 and into the early hours of June 4, as the army proceeded to clear the square, he attempted to negotiate an orderly evacuation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	35	3364	He was later arrested and spent a year and a half in jail without ever being formally sentenced. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	36	3470	THE ARTIST 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	37	3490	-- Cui Jian, the rocker (born 1961). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	38	3527	The "father of rock" in China appeared several times on Tiananmen Square in 1989, and one of his works, "Nothing to My Name", became the unofficial fight song of the student movement. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	39	3720	THE UNKNOWN HERO 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	40	3746	-- On June 5, the day after the crackdown, a young man placed himself in front of a column of tanks, preventing it from passing down the Avenue of Heavenly Peace in the heart of Beijing. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	41	3933	At one point he even mounted the front tank to appeal to its crew, but bystanders eventually dragged him away. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	42	4044	Photos and footage of the "Tank Man" immediately made top news around the world, and he went down in history as a symbol of peaceful and unarmed protesters confronting military repression. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	43	4233	His name remains unknown to this day. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	0	58	China faces dark memory of Tiananmen 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	1	169	Authorities in China are bracing for the 20th anniversary of the deadly June 4 crackdown on pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square, a pivotal moment that still haunts the nation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	2	361	The way the government will likely mark the sensitive date on Thursday -- with deafening silence -- shows it is keenly aware of the emotional scars that remain after the army ended six weeks of peaceful rallies in central Beijing. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	3	601	China's Communist leaders have made any discussion of the brutal quelling of the student-led demonstrations -- in which hundreds, maybe thousands, were killed -- taboo, but dissidents say the public could yet hold them accountable. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	4	842	"People remember this date because they want the Communist Party to take responsibility for the crimes it committed," said 53-year-old Qi Zhiyong, who lost a leg after being shot by troops near Tiananmen Square. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	5	1063	"It reminds them the party will resort to unbridled violence whenever it feels threatened." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	6	1164	In a bid not to rankle the wary authorities, the main public commemoration planned for Thursday will probably be silent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	7	1294	Activist groups have called on citizens simply to wear white -- the traditional colour of mourning -- to honour those killed in the mayhem that erupted when tanks and troops rolled in to crush the protests. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	8	1510	The year 1989 was a disastrous one for communism across the globe and in China the ruling party found itself in a struggle with democracy activists who challenged its authoritarian rule over the world's most populous nation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	9	1744	The Tiananmen movement began in mid-April, when public grief over the death of former party leader and popular reformer Hu Yaobang gradually morphed into bold calls from students for political reform and steps to combat corruption. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	10	1985	Young students started to occupy Tiananmen Square, the symbolic centre of political power in China. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	11	2085	A sense of euphoria saturated the plaza as they took part in rallies no one would have thought possible just weeks earlier. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	12	2218	"There were banners everywhere. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	13	2250	This was the first unauthorised political demonstration in the (history of the) People's Republic of China," recalled one of the student leaders, Wang Dan. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	14	2415	Calls for democracy and freedom filled the square, thousands went on hunger strike, and one charismatic activist, Wu'er Kaixi, brazenly challenged Premier Li Peng during a meeting broadcast live on state television. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	15	2640	Indeed, the whole world was watching, as news crews from around the globe gathered in Beijing to cover the historic visit by then Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, only to stumble upon an event that would be far more significant. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	16	2878	In the corridors of power, the protests drove a wedge between hardline leaders led by Premier Li and moderates headed by Communist Party general secretary Zhao Ziyang. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	17	3055	The hardliners won, with patriarch Deng Xiaoping, China's most powerful man, tilting the balance in their favour. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	18	3169	Zhao was removed from his post as party leader and spent 16 years under house arrest until his death in 2005. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	19	3288	The student movement was declared a "counterrevolutionary rebellion", and soldiers of the People's Liberation Army descended on the capital, crushing the democratic dreams of an entire generation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	20	3494	The number of people killed in the night of June 3-4 remains a mystery. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	21	3566	China's official death toll is 241, including 36 students. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	22	3625	Dissidents say thousands may have died. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	23	3674	The crackdown set off a wave of condemnation across the globe, and for several years China was treated as a near-pariah, as Western governments offered asylum to student leaders fleeing into exile. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	24	3881	The international community has long since welcomed China back into the fold, and Beijing's communist leaders have cemented their hold on power, transforming the country into the world's number three economy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	25	4099	But they have shown no willingness to change their position that the protests threatened Communist Party rule and had to be quelled in order to maintain economic reforms. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	26	4279	"Facts have proven that the socialist road with Chinese characteristics that we pursue is in the fundamental interests of our people," foreign ministry spokesman Ma Zhaoxu told journalists in May. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	27	4485	But, undeterred, victims of the crackdown have called for renewed international pressure on Beijing to reverse the official verdict on the quelling, saying failure to stand up to a rising China tacitly abets the repression. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	28	4718	"So far, the international community... has adopted a policy of appeasement towards the Chinese government," said Ding Zilin, 72, whose teenage son was shot dead by the army. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	29	4902	Bao Tong -- a former aide to Zhao who was jailed for seven years following the crackdown -- said the world has failed to push China to be more open about the events of Tiananmen because of Beijing's increasing global clout. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	30	5135	"Not wanting to offend China means they cannot help China, cannot help China's people attain their own rights, and cannot help the world community gain a reliable, stable, peaceful member," Bao told AFP recently. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	31	5357	"This is not a good thing," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	32	5404	Bao has since been ordered to sit out the anniversary at a resort more than 1,000 kilometres (625 miles) from Beijing -- evidence that the authorities in the capital are not yet ready to reopen the Tiananmen wounds.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0449	2	279	Hundreds, perhaps thousands, were killed on June 3-4, 1989.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	0	58	US urges rejection of Guantanamo Uighurs case 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	1	208	President Barack Obama's administration has asked the Supreme Court to reject a request by Chinese Uighurs held at the Guantanamo Bay prison and cleared of all charges to be released on US soil. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	2	412	The petitioners "have already obtained relief. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	3	459	They are no longer being detained as enemy combatants," wrote US Solicitor General Elena Kagan in the administration's filing to the Supreme Court Friday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	4	623	Kagan wrote that the men, members of a Turkic-speaking Muslim minority who fear persecution if returned to China, "are being housed in relatively unrestricted conditions given the status of Guantanamo Bay as a United States military base." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	5	872	Four years ago US authorities cleared the 17 imprisoned Uighurs, but they are stuck at the Guantanamo prison due to fears that Beijing would torture them if they returned to their homeland in northwestern China's remote Xinjiang province. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	6	1120	At the prison, the Uighurs are held at "Camp Iguana," a special area for detainees cleared for release. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	7	1224	They have more freedom and greater privileges than most other prisoners, including a recreational space and a library, according to the Pentagon. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	8	1379	In October 2008 a federal judge ordered that the Uighurs be released in the United States. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	9	1470	The most likely place for the detainees to be released would be in Washington's suburbs in northern Virginia, which is home to a significant Uighur expatriate community. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	10	1649	A federal appeals court in February however overturned that ruling. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	11	1717	It is the Uighurs' appeal to that decision that the Supreme Court must now address. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	12	1810	But for the Obama administration, which is repeating some of the reasoning that his predecessor George W. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	13	1916	Bush used, "the decision whether to allow aliens abroad to enter the United States and if so, under what terms, rests exclusively in the political branches," according to the filing, which AFP obtained a copy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	14	2135	For the government, the "petitioners' continued presence at Guantanamo Bay is not unlawful detention but rather the consequence of their lawful exclusion from the United States under the constitutional exercise of authority by the political branches, coupled with the unavailability of another country willing to accept them," Kagan wrote. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	15	2484	The nine justices sitting on the US high court have not yet said whether they would examine the politically explosive case, and could announce a decision by June. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	16	2656	The legal case was filed by 14 of the 17 Uighur prisoners. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	17	2724	The Guantanamo camp was established by the Bush administration as an offshore prison for "war on terror" detainees. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	18	2840	Some 800 youth and adults have passed through the prison camp and about 240 remain today. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	19	2939	The US navy established a base in Guantanamo Bay at the end of the 1898 Spanish- American War, then signed a long-term lease with the Cuban government. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	20	3091	Cuba's communist government has been demanding its return since the 1960s.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	1	189	US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton risks walking into what one analyst calls a Latin American minefield over ties with Cuba when she visits El Salvador and neighboring Honduras this week. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	2	389	The issue will hover over Monday's inauguration of new Salvadoran president Mauricio Funes in San Salvador and could cause a rift at the Organization of American States (OAS) general assembly in San Pedro Sula, Honduras on Tuesday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	3	630	US officials could not even rule out the possibility of Clinton's skipping the OAS meeting altogether if negotiators fail to agree on terms for bringing Cuba back within the 35-member organization's fold. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	4	844	The United States wants Cuba to free political prisoners and respect political freedoms for it to participate fully in the OAS, saying it is holding the body to the democratic principles enshrined in its own 2001 charter. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	5	1075	Other OAS members say that Cuba can be nudged toward democracy once inside the OAS. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	6	1168	Many members point out that the reason for Cuba's suspension in 1962 -- its role in the Cold War-era Soviet bloc -- does not apply today as the bloc no longer exists. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	7	1344	Even though Cuba itself rejects the OAS, analysts said, many countries want to use the issue to either push for a lifting of the decades-old US embargo on Havana or for their own private agendas, such as to embarrass the United States. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	8	1589	Since a popular US President Barack Obama took office in January, he has raised hopes among many of his southern neighbors that he will soon lift the embargo, even if he insists that Cuba first undertake democratic reforms. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	9	1822	"This is going to be a complicated challenge for her (Clinton) to deal with," said Michael Shifter, an analyst for the Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington think tank. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	10	2000	"I sense the Obama people are a little bit nervous. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	11	2052	I think they're aware that it's a minefield, Cuba," said Shifter who pointed to the risk of a rift within the OAS. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	12	2176	And Clinton's stop in San Salvador "creates a certain dynamic," Shifter said, because the presence of a Cuban leader at the inauguration will mark the start of El Salvador's own moves toward full diplomatic ties with Cuba. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	13	2408	It will expose the US position even more because, under the previous US-backed right-wing government, El Salvador was the last Latin American countries not to have normal relations with Cuba, he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	14	2618	Shifter said he has heard that Cuban President Raul Castro is attending, but AFP was unable to confirm the information. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	15	2747	Asked if Clinton would meet with the Cubans at the inauguration, a senior US official said on the condition of anonymity: "We're not at the stage right now where the secretary would meet with Cuban officials." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	16	2966	Shifter said the OAS secretary general, Jose Miguel Insulza, as well as radical leftist Venezuela, Nicaragua and host country Honduras were driving the agenda to have Cuba readmitted to the OAS. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	17	3170	Instead of having Cuba as the burning issue, he said, the Obama team would have preferred to highlight a new era of US cooperation with leftist but pragmatic democratic governments like those in El Salvador, Brazil and Chile. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	18	3405	Her visit to San Salvador is symbolic of the shift because Funes brought to power the Farabundo Marti Front for National Liberation, former leftist guerrillas who fought the US-backed right-wing government in the 1980s civil war. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	19	3644	Chris Sabatini, an analyst with the Council of Americas, said the new administration is trying to show that the "tent of democracy is broad" even while a few leftist radicals remain in the region. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	20	3850	"It is an attempt to not so much isolate them (radicals) but to create a positive pole in the hemisphere of democrats that can't be easily labeled as just pro-US, but range across the ideological spectrum," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	21	4075	Sabatini also expected the consensus-driven OAS to come to some agreement on the Cuba issue, saying the current debate amounted to a "tempest in a teapot" and a distraction to important human rights issues.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	23	4358	A senior US State Department official told reporters late Friday "it's hard to say" when asked if a consensus would be reached. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	24	4495	Nor could he exclude the possibility that Clinton might have to skip the meeting. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	25	4577	"I can't answer that question," he said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0454	17	2723	GM also announced plans to retool an idled US plant to build small cars it had originally planned to import, and two more US assembly plants could potentially be saved. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0454	18	2901	The bankruptcy filing could also be sped up by a deal struck in the early hours Saturday after marathon talks that saw Canadian parts maker Magna and its Russian backers taking over GM's Opel.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0457	4	771	Tournaments such as the Indian Premier League (IPL) are now far more lucrative per match for a player than five-day Test cricket, the traditional pinnacle of the sport.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	0	58	Cricket: Unorthodox Van der Merwe adds punch to Proteas 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	1	193	He’s an unlikely cricket star - a short, stocky all-rounder with a mediocre first-class record - but Roelof van der Merwe has become a Twenty20 player to be reckoned with since he made his debut for South Africa in March. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	2	424	Van der Merwe’s nickname with his Titans franchise is 'Bulldog' and he lives up to it with his aggressive attitude as a left-arm slow bowler, hard-hitting right-handed batsman or in the field. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	3	626	Selected for the South African under-19 team in 2004, his cricket career seemed to hit a dead end and he admits he spent more time partying than working on his game in his first year or so after leaving school in Pretoria. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	4	858	He started attracting serious attention in the 2007/08 season with his economical bowling and effective pinch-hitting for the Titans in limited overs cricket, helping the franchise win both the 45-overs and 20-overs competition. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	5	1096	On Twenty20 international debut he top-scored with 48 against Australia with a frenzied mixture of wild hits and judicious bunts. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	6	1235	He swung his bat with such ferocity that one attempted pull shot flew off a top edge over point for one of his four sixes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	7	1367	Drafted into the South African one-day international side, he topped his side’s bowling averages and was the most economical bowler, twice taking three wickets in an innings in four appearances. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	8	1571	Snapped up by the Royal Challengers Bangalore, he became a regular member of the team that reached the final of the Indian Premier League. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	9	1719	While his batting appears agricultural, his bowling is canny. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	10	1790	He bowls with tight control and his franchise coach Richard Pybus said: "He has an instinct for anticipating what a batsman is going to do." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	11	1940	South African captain Graeme Smith likes Van der Merwe’s attitude. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	12	2016	"He really wants to be an active part of the game which, when you come in as a youngster, is important. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	13	2120	If you’re a bit sheepish then the game will test you." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	14	2184	No-one can accuse Van der Merwe of being sheepish. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	15	2244	When he takes a wicket he roars his delight and shakes his fists above his head like a victorious boxer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	16	2358	And he’s unbowed when teased about his batting style. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	17	2421	"It’s not how you drive, it’s how you arrive," he said when presented with the man of the match award in his first Twenty20 international. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	0	58	Cricket: Gloveman McCullum holds key for New Zealand 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	1	188	The weight of New Zealand's Twenty20 World Cup expectations rests heavily on the shoulders of Brendon McCullum and his burning desire to be recognised as the world's best wicketkeeper-batsman. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	2	390	The diminutive gloveman is the key element in New Zealand's game plan with his audacious batting at the top of the order and his lightning-fast reactions behind the woodwork. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	3	574	That the 27-year-old's name is often mentioned as a contender to inherit the mantle of Australian great Adam Gilchrist speaks volumes for his ability. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	4	734	In the Indian Premier League, the Kolkata Knight Riders valued McCullum at 700,000 US dollars, the biggest offer for a New Zealand player, when they snapped him up last year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	5	918	They were immediately rewarded when he launched the inaugural IPL series by smashing a record 158 off 73 balls and he ended the season with an average 62.66 with the bat at a strike rate of 204.35. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	6	1125	New Zealand's 2008 Player of the Year has also won high praise from Australia where a cameo McCullum performance helped New South Wales qualify for the Champions League Twenty20 tournament in October. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	7	1335	"There is no doubt having Brendon McCullum in your team increases your chances of a win, that is an undeniable fact," said Cricket NSW chief executive David Gilbert. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	8	1510	In the just-completed second IPL series leading up to the World Twenty20, McCullum's batting was below par by his usual standards, finishing with an average of 23.75 at a strike rate of 119.24. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	9	1713	But ominiously, McCullum was working his way into form as the World Twenty20 approached with two knocks in the 80s in his last four IPL innings. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	10	1867	In a side which struggles for consistancy, much is made of whether McCullum's best role with the bat is as a blockbusting opener or an aggressive middle-order hitter who can get New Zealand across the finish line. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	11	2090	Coach Andy Moles is adamant he will lead with McCullum in partnership with the emerging Jesse Ryder. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	12	2200	"Opening is Brendon's place," he said with memories still fresh of the way McCullum engineered a clean sweep over India in their Twenty20 two-match series in February. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	13	2377	McCullum carried his bat through both innings and in a dramatic finish to the second game he calmly stroked a single off the final ball to secure the win. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	14	2541	New Zealand will rely on that same McCullum calmness to get them through the World Twenty20, while the gloveman will be looking to enhance his own reputation as well as aiding his country. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0470	15	2739	"I want to be the best batsman-keeper in the world," he told the New Zealand Herald. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0471	0	58	Cricket: Porterfield aiming for more Irish success 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0471	1	182	Ireland may be heading into the World Twenty20 without their best player but captain William Porterfield believes the side can still achieve great things during the tournament. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0471	2	368	The Irish have seen star batsman Eoin Morgan called up by England just as was the case ahead of the 2007 World Cup in the Caribbean with Ed Joyce. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0471	3	524	But five years ago Ireland still managed to beat Pakistan and Bangladesh - one of their Group A opponents along with World Twenty20 champions India. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0471	4	682	Porterfield, an opening batsman who plays English county cricket for Gloucestershire, is hoping the form Ireland showed in dominating the 2011 World Cup qualifying tournament in South Africa and then by thrashing Worcestershire by 94 runs in an English Friends Provident Trophy 50-overs per side match, will carry on into the World Twenty20. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0471	5	1033	He has already shown he knows how to play a captain's innings - his 69 off 110 balls was central to Ireland's win over Worcestershire - and Porterfield reckons the side are getting better all the time 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0471	6	1243	"The nucleus of the squad is still there from the 2007 World Cup. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0471	7	1309	And we've added the likes of Peter Connell and Regan West. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0471	8	1377	"We now have more depth and there's more quality to choose from." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0471	9	1452	Porterfield may be one day lost to Ireland, just as Morgan and Joyce have been. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0471	10	1541	But in the meantime his experience of top-class cricket - his 85 was vital in the 2007 World Cup win over Bangladesh - could help the Irish again make a mark in a global event.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	1	181	Scotland captain Gavin Hamilton hopes the World Twenty20 will enable his side to get back on track following their surprise failure to qualify for the 2011 World Cup. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	2	357	Long one of the most consistent nations outside the Test elite, a run of poor results during the recent 2011 qualifying tournament in South Africa saw Scotland fail to make it to the showpiece event in Asia. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	3	574	Ryan Watson was stripped of the captaincy and in his place came all-rounder Hamilton, whose one and only Test appearance a decade ago for England saw him fail to take a wicket and record a pair against South Africa in Johannesburg. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	4	815	Now 34, Hamilton's career in England was to suffer dramatically when a move from Yorkshire to Durham saw him get what golfers would term the 'yips' with his seam bowling. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	5	995	But he has been able to continue his Scotland career and now Hamilton hopes a new-look side can give a good account of themselves in a Group D also featuring South Africa and New Zealand. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	6	1192	"We're realistic about our chances of winning games, but if there's ever a game to win, it's Twenty20 because the whole thing can turn around in two or three overs," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	7	1376	"It's a case of having people playing well and hopefully catching teams on a semi-bad day." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	8	1477	Scotland face England in a warm-up match on Tuesday at Trent Bridge but Hamilton said his 1999 experience would not be something he would dwell on. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	9	1634	"That was a long time ago," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	10	1671	"I had my ups and downs thinking about that in the couple of years after it. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	11	1748	But not now. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	12	1770	"It was an experience I'd like to change but I came away from that tour a better cricketer."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	0	58	Cricket: Broad looking for better headlines 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	1	175	England quick Stuart Broad goes into the World Twenty20 determined to make the most of a tournament often seen as a hiding to nothing for bowlers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	2	331	Broad, at 22 an improving paceman and a more than handy lower order batsman, is quickly becoming an important member of the England team. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	3	478	But it says something about the self-belief of the son of former England opening batsman Chris that his confidence was not dented permanently when, during the corresponding tournament in South Africa two years ago, he became the first bowler to be hit for six sixes in an over during a Twenty20 international by India's Yuvraj Singh in Durban. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	4	831	"Anyone can get hit," said Broad. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	5	865	"You can see that in the amount of Twenty20 cricket that is being played now. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	6	952	"They bring the boundaries in, they make it smaller and everyone wants to see fours and sixes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	7	1047	So, as a bowler, you've got to accept sometimes you're going to be on the receiving end. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	8	1145	"The important thing is how you bounce back, how you improve as a bowler and how you learn new deliveries and practice different skills. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	9	1291	"It's important, certainly at a young age, to learn from it, take it in your stride and turn everything into a positive. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	10	1421	"It was a chance to really improve me as a bowler and I couldn't be happier with the way the last year has gone." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	11	1544	England were off the pace in South Africa, failing to beat a major nation during a run of just one win in five matches. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	12	1673	But they will have home advantage on their side in a group that sees them take on Pakistan, losing finalists in 2007, and outsiders the Netherlands. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	13	1831	"I think hosting the event is a massive plus for us," said Broad. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	14	1897	"Twenty20 is really big in England on the domestic side so to be having the World Twenty20 is going to make the crowds even more excitable." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	15	2047	And while Andrew Flintoff's latest injury, a knee problem, has ruled the star all-rounder out of the tournament, Broad said it was time England stopped despairing when confronted with life without 'Fred'. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	16	2261	"When he's not in the side someone else gets given the ball and takes responsibility," Broad explained. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	17	2374	"I thrive on that extra responsibility and I certainly like taking the new ball. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	18	2455	We talk about the first 10 overs setting the tone and that's my job with Jimmy Anderson."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	0	58	Football: Rangers on holiday, happy with domestic double 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	1	189	Rangers assistant manager Ally McCoist said he was looking forward to his summer break after a Nacho Novo wonder strike won the Scottish Cup as the Gers secured a domestic double. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	2	378	The Ibrox side's narrow 1-0 victory over a battling Falkirk side means Rangers can add the Scottish Cup to the Scottish Premier League championship they won on the final day of the season. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	3	576	It brings to a close a long season for the Ibrox side which begun with a Champions League qualifier against FBK Kaunas on July 30 last year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	4	726	The Glasgow giants, who the season before had reached the UEFA Cup final, suffered a painful elimination from Europe at the hands of the Lithuanian minnows. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	5	892	And while McCoist says the club will look to buy more players in the summer, the fact they put the disappointment of the Kaunas defeat behind them to secure a league and cup double was testament to the effort the players had put in since he and Walter Smith returned to the club in January 2007. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	6	1197	"It can always get better in terms of the team and the squad. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	7	1259	With a bit of luck we can maybe add to that and look to strengthen," McCoist said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	8	1351	"But in terms of what the boys achieved in the last two years the team deserve all the credit going. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	9	1461	"Last year was so close to being the best season in the club's history. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	10	1533	It ended up being, in many people's eyes, a disappointment when we lost the league on the final day. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	11	1643	"We can sit and talk about it all day if we deserved or we didn't deserve it. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	12	1721	The fact is we didn't win it. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	13	1760	"I just felt that this year it was a real reward for the players." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	14	1836	McCoist added: "I am absolutely looking forward to my break like you have no idea. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	15	1919	I've got the golf clubs looked out and hopefully I'll take a few quid off the manager in the summer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	16	2029	"I think the players will be looking forward to getting away from us more but they really need a break, especially with last season when they didn't get as much of a break as we would've liked." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	17	2233	McCoist also heaped praise on striker Novo, who scored 36 seconds after coming off the bench at half-time. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	18	2349	The Spaniard collected a Sasa Papac throw-in to send a sensational strike past Falkirk keeper Dani Mello from 30 yards out as the Ibrox side lifted the Scottish Cup for the 33rd time. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	19	2542	And McCoist, himself a legendary striker with the Gers, said it was a goal worthy of winning any cup final. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0484	20	2659	"It was very good.
